tgt_text.481: " Most glorious Jove, greatest of ever-living gods, choose which of these your inclination within your breast bids you."
tgt_text.482: He spake, I ween, in subtlety:
tgt_text.483: but Jove knowing imperish­ able counsels was aware, in soothe and not ignorant of his guile;
tgt_text.484: and was boding in his heart evils to mortal men, which also were about to find accomplishment.
tgt_text.485: Then with both hands lifted he up the white fat.
tgt_text.486: But he was incensed in mind, and wrath came around him in spirit, when he saw the white bones of the ox arranged with guileful art.
tgt_text.487: And thenceforth the tribes of men on the earth burn to the im­ mortals white bones1 on fragrant altars.
tgt_text.488: Then cloud-com­ pelling Jove addressed him, greatly displeased:
tgt_text.489: " Son of Iapetus, skilled in wise plans beyond all, you do not, good sir, I wot, yet forget subtle art."
tgt_text.490: Thus spake in his wrath Jove knowing imperishable counsels:
tgt_text.491: from that time forward in truth, ever mindful of the fraud, he did not give the strength of untiring fire to wretched mortal men, who dwell upon the earth.
tgt_text.492: But the good son of Iapetus cheated him,2 and stole the far- seen splendour of untiring fire in a hollow fennel-stalk;
tgt_text.493: but it stung high-thundering Jove to his heart's core, and incensed his spirit, when he saw the radiance of fire conspicuous among men.
tgt_text.494: Forthwith then wrought he evil for men in requital for the fire bestowed.
tgt_text.495: For from the earth the famous Vulcan, halting in both feet, fashioned3 the image of a modest maiden, through the counsels of the son of Cronus.
tgt_text.496: And the goddess glancing-eyed Minerva girded and arrayed her in silver-white raiment;
tgt_text.497: and from her head she held with her bands.
tgt_text.498: a curiously embroidered veil, a marvel to look upon:
tgt_text.499: and Pallas Athene placed around her about her head lovely garlands fresh-budding with meadow-flowers, and around her bead she set a golden coronet,5 which renowned Vulcan lame with both feet had made himself, having wrought it carefully by hand, out of compliment to Jove his sire.
tgt_text.500: On it had been wrought many curious monsters, a marvel to view, as many as in great abundance the continent and the sea maintain.
tgt_text.501: Many of these he introduced, (and much elegance beamed from it,) of wondrous beauty, like to living animals gifted with sounds.
tgt_text.502: But when he had wrought a beauteous evil1 instead of good, he led her forth even where were the rest of gods and men, exulting as sAe was in the adornment of the gleaming- eyed daughter-of-a-strong-father:
tgt_text.503: and wonder seized immortal gods as well as mortal men, when they beheld a deep snare, against which man's arts are vain.
tgt_text.504: Now from her is the race of tender women.
tgt_text.506: For from her is a pernicious race, and tribes of women, a great source of hurt, dwell along with mor­ tal men,3 helpmates not of consuming poverty, but of surfeit.
tgt_text.507: And as when in close-roofed hives bees feed drones, sharers in bad works,4 the former through the whole day till sunset are busy day by day, and make white combs, whilst the latter, remaining within in the close-roofed hives, reap the labours of others for their own maws.
tgt_text.508: Just so to mortal men high-thundering Jove gave women as an evil, helpmates of painful toils:
tgt_text.509: another evil too did he provide instead of good;
tgt_text.510: to Mit, whosoever shunning mar­ riage and the ills that women work, declines to marry, and has come to old age pernicious,1 through want of one to tend his latter days;
tgt_text.511: he lives not, it is true, in lack of subsistence, but, when he is dead, distant kindred divide his possessions:
tgt_text.512: whilst to whomsoever, on the other hand, the lot of marriage shall have fallen, and he has had a good wife congenial to his heart, to him then for ever ill contends with good2 to be with him:
tgt_text.513: but whoso finds a baneful breed, lives with an incessant3 care to spirit and heart within his breast, and is an irremedi­ able woe.
tgt_text.514: Thus it is not possible to deceive or overreach4 the mind of Jove, for neither did Prometheus, guileless son of Iapetus, escape from beneath his severe wrath;
tgt_text.515: but a great chain, by necessity, constrains him, very knowing though he is.
tgt_text.516: But when first their sire5 became wroth in spirit against Briareus, Cottus, and Gyes, he bound them with a strong bond, admiring their overweening courage, and also their form and bulk;
tgt_text.517: and he made them dwell beneath the roomy earth:
tgt_text.518: then they in sooth in grief dwelling 'neath the earth,1 sate at the verge, on the extremities of vast Earth, very long, afflicted, having a great woe at heart;
tgt_text.519: but them the son of Cronus, and other immortal gods, whom fair-haired Rhea bare in the embrace of Cronus, by the counsels of Earth brought up again to light:
tgt_text.520: for she recounted to them at large everything, how that they should along with those (Titans) gain victory and splendid glory.
tgt_text.521: Long time then they fought, incurring soul-vexing toil, the Titan gods and as many as were born from Cronus, in opposition to each other in stout conflicts;
tgt_text.522: the one side,2 the glorious Titans from lofty Othrys, and the other, I wot, the gods, givers of good things, whom Rhea the fair-haired had borne to Cronus, in union with him, from Olympus.
tgt_text.523: They then, I ween, in soul-distressing battle, one party with the other, were fighting continuously more than ten years.
tgt_text.525: Nor was there any riddance or end of severe contention to either party, and the completion4 of the war was extended equally to either.
tgt_text.526: But when at length Jove set before them5 all things agreeable, to wit, nectar and ambrosia, on which the gods themselves feed, a noble spirit grew in the breasts of all.
tgt_text.527: And when they had tasted the nectar and delightful ambrosia, then at length the sire of gods and men addressed them:
tgt_text.528: “Hear me, illustrious children of Earth and Heaven, that I may speak what my spirit within my breast prompts me to speak.
tgt_text.529: For now a very long space6 are we fighting, each in opposition to other, concerning victory and power, all our days, the Titan gods and as many of us as are sprung from Cronus.
tgt_text.530: Now do ye show against the Titans in deadly fight both mighty force and hands in­ vincible, in gratitude for our mild loving-kindness, namely, after how many sufferings ye came back again to the light, from afflictive bondage, through our counsels,1 from the murky gloom."
tgt_text.532: and him again the blameless Cottus addressed in answer:
tgt_text.533: “Excellent Lord, thou dost not tell things unlearnt by us:
tgt_text.534: but we too are aware that thy wisdom is excellent, and excellent thine intellect, and that thou hast been to the immortals an averter of terrible destruction.
tgt_text.536: And back again, from harsh bonds, have we come from the murky darkness, through thy thoughtful care, 0 royal son of Cronus, having experienced treatment unhoped-for.2
tgt_text.537: Wherefore also now with stedfast purpose and prudent counsel we will pro­ tect thy might in dread conflict, fighting with the Titans in stout battles."
tgt_text.539: and the gods, givers of good, applauded, when they had heard his speech:
tgt_text.540: and their spirit was eager for battle still more than before, and they stirred up unhappy3 strife all of them, female as well as male, on that day, both Titan gods, and as many as had sprung from Cro­ nus, and they whom Jove sent up to light from Erebus, be­ neath the earth, terrible and strong, having overweening force.
tgt_text.541: From the shoulders of these a hundred hands outsprung to all alike, and to each fifty heads grew from their shoulders over their sturdy limbs.
tgt_text.542: They then were pitted5 against the Titans in deadly combat, holding huge1 rocks in their sturdy hands.
tgt_text.543: But the Titans on the other side made strong their squadrons with alacrity, and both parties were showing work of hand and force at the same time, and the boundless sea re­ echoed terribly, and earth resounded loudly, and broad heaven groaned, being shaken, and vast Olympus was convulsed from its base under the violence of the immortals,2 and a severe quaking came to murky Tartarus,3 namely, a hollow sound of countless chase of feet, and of strong battle-strokes:
tgt_text.544: to such an extent, I ween, did they hurl groan-causing weapons.
tgt_text.545: And the voice of both parties reached to starry heaven, as they cheered:
tgt_text.546: for they came together with a great war-cry.
tgt_text.547: Nor longer, in truth, did Jove restrain his fury, but ther.
tgt_text.548: forthwith his heart was filled with fierceness, and he begar.
tgt_text.549: also to exhibit4 all his force:
tgt_text.550: then, I wot, from heaven ant.
tgt_text.551: from Olympus together he went forth lightening continually and the bolts close together with thunder and lightning flew1 duly from his sturdy hand, whirling a sacred flash, in fre­ quent1 succession, while all-around life-giving Earth was crashing in conflagration, and the immense forests on all sides crackled loudly with fire.
tgt_text.552: All land was boiling, and Oceanis streams, and the barren sea:
tgt_text.553: warm vapour was cir­ cling the earth-born Titans, and the incessant blaze reached the divine dense-atmosphere,2 whilst flashing radiance of thunderbolt and lightning was bereaving their eyes of sight, strong heroes though they were.
tgt_text.554: Fearful heat likewise pos­ sessed Chaos:
tgt_text.555: 3 and it seemed, to look at, face to face, with the eye, and to hear the sound with the ear, just as if earth and broad heaven from above were threatening to meet:
tgt_text.556: (for such an exceeding crash would have arisen from earth falling in ruins, and heaven dashing it down from above.)
tgt_text.557: Such a din there rose when the gods clashed in strife.
tgt_text.558: The winds too at the same time were stirring up quaking and dust to­ gether, thunder and lightning and smoking bolt, shafts of the mighty Jove;
tgt_text.559: and they were bearing shout and battle-cry into the midst, one of another, then a terrible noise of dread­ ful strife was roused, strength of prowess was put forth, and the battle was inclined :
tgt_text.560: but before that time assailing one an­ other, they were fighting4 incessantly in stern conflict.
tgt_text.561: Now the others, I wot, among the first ranks roused the keen fight, Cottus, Briareus, and Gyes insatiable in war, who truly were hurling from sturdy hands three hundred rocks close upon each other, and they had overshadowed the Titans with mis­ siles, sent them 'neath the broad-wayed earth, and bound them in irksome bonds, (having conquered them with their hands, over-haughty though they were,) as far beneath under earth1 as heaven is from the earth, for equal is the space from earth to murky Tartarus.
tgt_text.562: For nine nights and days also would a brazen anvil be descending from the heaven, and come on the tenth to the earth:
tgt_text.563: and nine days as well as nights again would a brazen anvil be descending from the earth, to reach on the tenth to Tartarus.
tgt_text.565: Around it moreover a brazen fence3 has been forged:
tgt_text.566: and about it Night is poured in three rows around the neck;
tgt_text.567: but above spring the roots of Earth and barren Sea.
tgt_text.568: There, under murky darkness, the Titan gods lie hidden4 by the counsels of cloud-compelling Jupiter in a dark, drear place, where oreb the extremities of vast Earth.
tgt_text.569: These may not go forth, for Neptune has placed above them brazen gates, and a wall goes round them on both sides.
tgt_text.571: There dwell Gyes, and Cottus, and high-spirited Briareus, faithful guards of aegis-bearing Jove.
tgt_text.572: And there are the sources and boundaries of dusky Earth, of murky Tartarus, of barren Sea, and starry Heaven, all in their order:
tgt_text.573: boundaries op­ pressive and gloomy, which also even gods abhor, a vast chasm, 1 not even for a whole round of a year would one reach the pavement, after having first been within the gates:
tgt_text.574: but hurricane to hurricane would bear him onward2 hither and thither, distressing him, and dreadful even to immortal gods is this prodigy, and there the dread abodes of gloomy Night stand shrouded in dark clouds.
tgt_text.575: In front of these the son of Iapetus stands and holds 3 broad Heaven, with his head and unwearied hands, unmovedly, where Night and Day also drawing nigh are wont to salute each other,4 as they cross the vast brazen threshold.
tgt_text.576: The one is about to go down within, whilst the other comes forth abroad, nor ever doth the abode constrain both within ;
tgt_text.577: but constantly one at any rate being outside the dwelling, wanders over the earth, while the other again beingwithin the abode, awaits5 the season of her journey, until it come ;
tgt_text.578: the one having a far-seeing light for men-on- the-earth, and the other, destructive Night, having Sleep, the brother of Death, in its hands, being shrouded in hazy mist.
tgt_text.580: And there the sons of obscure Night hold their habitation, Sleep and Death, dread gods:
tgt_text.581: nor ever doth the bright sun look upon them with his rays,7 as he ascends the heaven, or descends from the heaven.
tgt_text.582: Of whom indeed the one tarries on the earth and the broad surface of the sea, silently and soothingly to men;
tgt_text.583: but of the other, iron is the heart, and brazen is his ruthless soul within his breast;
tgt_text.584: and whomsoever of men he may have first caught, he holdeth:
tgt_text.585: and he is hos­ tile even to immortal gods.
tgt_text.586: There in the front stand the re­ sounding mansions of the infernal god, of mighty Hades, and awful2 Persephone besides;
tgt_text.587: and a fierce dog keeps guard in front, a ruthless dog;
tgt_text.588: and he has an evil trick:
tgt_text.589: those who enter he fawns upon with his tail and both ears3 alike, yet he suffers them not to go forth back again, but lies in wait and devours whomsoever he may have caught going forth without the gates of strong Hades and dread Persephone.
tgt_text.590: There too dwells a goddess odious to immortals, dread Styx, eldest daughter of back-flowing" Ocean:
tgt_text.591: and apart from the gods she inhabits renowned dwellings vaulted by huge rocks;
tgt_text.592: and round about on all sides they are strengthened to Heaven by silver columns.
tgt_text.593: And seldom goes the fleet-footed daughter of Than mas, Iris, on a message5 over the broad back of the sea,6 namely, when haply strife and quarrel shall have arisen among the immortals:
tgt_text.594: and whosoever, I wot, of them that hold Olym­ pian dwellings, utters falsehood, then also Jove7 is wont to send Iris to bring from far in a golden ewer the great oath of the gods, the renowned water, cold as it is, which also runs down from a steep and lofty rock ;
tgt_text.595: but in abundance beneath the roomy Earth flows a branch of Ocean from the sacred river through black Night;
tgt_text.596: and a tenth portion has been assigned 1 to it.
tgt_text.597: In nine portions indeed, rolling around Earth and also the broad back of the Sea with silver whirlpools, he (Ocean) falls into the brine;
tgt_text.598: but the other one part flows forth from a rock, a great bane to the gods.
tgt_text.599: Whosoever of im­ mortals that occupy the top of snowy Olympus, shall have offered of this2 as a libation, and sworn over it a false oath, lies breathless until the completion of a year,3 nor ever comes near the repast of nectar and ambrosia, but also lies breath­ less and speechless on a strown couch, and a baneful stupor over-shrouds him.
tgt_text.600: But when he has fulfilled his malady until the full year, then another after another severer trouble suc­ ceeds for him.
tgt_text.601: And for nine years he is parted from the ever- living gods;
tgt_text.602: nor ever does he mix with them in council nor in feasts for nine whole years;
tgt_text.603: but in the tenth he mingles again in the assemblies4 of the gods immortal, who occupy Olympian dwellings.
tgt_text.604: Such a grave oath, I wot, have the gods made the imperishable water of Styx, that ancient Ma­ ter, which also runs through a very rugged tract.
tgt_text.605: There too are the sources and boundaries of dusky Earth, and murky Tartarus, and barren Sea, and starry Heaven, all in order;
tgt_text.606: boundaries oppressive and gloomy, which also even gods ab­ hor.
tgt_text.607: And there are gleaming5 gates and a brazen threshold, unshaken and fixed upon far-extending foundations, self- growing ;
tgt_text.608: and before it, outside of all the gods, beyond gloomy Chaos, the Titans dwell.
tgt_text.609: But the famed allies6 of loud- crashing Jove inhabit dwellings under the foundations of the Ocean, namely, Cottus and Gyes.
tgt_text.610: Briareus indeed, for his part, strong as he was, deep-sounding Earth-shaker made his son-in-law, and gave him to wife his daughter Cymopolia.
tgt_text.611: But when Jove had driven the Titans out from Heaven, huge Earth bare her youngest-born son, Typhoeus,1 by the embrace of Tartarus, through golden Aphrodite.
tgt_text.612: Whose hands, indeed, are apt for deeds on the score of strength, and untiring the feet of the strong god;
tgt_text.613: and from his shoulders there were a hundred heads of a serpent, a fierce dragon, play­ ing with dusky2 tongues, and from the eyes in his wondrous heads fire sparkled beneath the brows:
tgt_text.614: whilst from all his heads fire was gleaming, as he looked keenly.
tgt_text.615: In all his ter­ rible heads, too, were voices sending forth every kind of sound ineffable.
tgt_text.616: For one while indeed they would utter sounds, so as for the gods to understand,3 and at another time again the voice of a loud-bellowing bull, untameable in force, and proud in utterance ;
tgt_text.617: at another time, again, that of a lion possessing a daring spirit;
tgt_text.618: at another yet again they would sound like to whelps, wondrous to hear;
tgt_text.619: and at another he would hiss, and the lofty mountains resound.
tgt_text.620: And, in sooth, then would there have been done a deed past remedy, and he, even he, would have reigned over mortals and immortals, unless, I wot, the sire of gods and men had quickly observed him.
tgt_text.621: Harshly then he, thundered, and heavily, and terribly the earth re­ echoed around;
tgt_text.622: and the broad heaven above, and the sea, and streams of ocean, and the abysses of earth.
tgt_text.623: But beneath his immortal feet1 vast Olympus trembled, as the king uprose, and earth groaned beneath.
tgt_text.624: And the heat from both2 caught the dark-coloured sea, both of the thunder and lightning, and fire from the monster, the heat arising from the thunder-storms, winds, and burning lightning.
tgt_text.625: And all earth and heaven and sea were boiling;
tgt_text.626: and huge billows roared around the shores about and around, beneath the violence of gods;
tgt_text.628: Pluto trembled, monarch over the dead beneath ;
tgt_text.629: and the Titans under Tartarus, standing about Cro­ nus,3 trembled also, on account of the unceasing tumult and dreadful contention.
tgt_text.630: But Jove, when in truth he had raised high4 his wrath, and had taken his arms, his thunder and lightning, and smoking bolt, leapt up, and smote him from Olympus, and scorched5 all-around all the wondrous heads of the terrible monster.
tgt_text.631: But when at length he had quelled it, after having smitten it with blows, the monster fell down lamed, and huge Earth groaned.
tgt_text.632: But the flame from the lightning-blasted monster6 flashed forth in the mountain-hollows, hidden and rugged, when he was stricken, and much was the vast earth burnt and melted by the boundless vapour, like as pewter,7 heated by the art of youths, and by the well-bored melting-pit;
tgt_text.633: or iron, which is the hardest of metals, subdued in the dells of the mountain by blazing fire, melts in the sacred earth beneath the hands of Vulcan.
tgt_text.634: So, I wot, was earth melted in the glare of burning fire.
tgt_text.635: Then, troubled in spirit, he hurled him into wide Tartarus.
tgt_text.636: Now from Typhoeus1 is the strength of winds moist-blow­ ing, except the south-west, the north, and Argestes, and Ze­ phyr, who also indeed are a race from the gods, a great bless­ ing to mortals.
tgt_text.637: But the others, being random gusts, breathe over the sea.
tgt_text.638: And these in truth falling upon the darksome deep, rage with baneful hurricane, a great hurt to mortals;
tgt_text.639: and now here, now there they blow, and scatter barks, and destroy sailors:
tgt_text.640: nor is there any succour from ill to men, who encounter them on the ocean.
tgt_text.641: But these again even o'er the boundless flowery earth spoil the pleasant works of earth- born men, filling them with dust and wearisome uproar.
tgt_text.642: But when, I wot, the blessed gods had fulfilled their labour, and contended with the Titans perforce on the score of hon­ ours,2 then it was, I say, that they urged far-seeing Jove, by the advice of Earth, to rule and reign over immortals:
tgt_text.643: and he duly distributed honours amongst them.
tgt_text.644: And Jupiter, king of the gods, made Metis first his wife;
tgt_text.645: Metis, most wise of deities as well as mortal men.
tgt_text.646: But when now at length she was about to give birth to Minerva, gleam- ing-eyed goddess, then it was that having by deceit beguiled her mind with flattering words, he placed her within his own belly by the advice of Earth, and of starry Heaven.
tgt_text.648: For thus they persuaded him, lest other of everliving gods should possess2 sovereign honour in the room of Jove.
tgt_text.649: For of her it was fated that wise children should be born:
tgt_text.650: first the glancing-eyed Tritonian maiden, having equal might and prudent counsel with her sire;
tgt_text.651: and then, I ween, she was going to give-birth-to a son, as king of gods and men, with an overbearing spirit, but that in sooth Jove deposited her first in his own belly, that the goddess might indicate to him both good and bad.
tgt_text.653: Next he wedded bright Themis,4 who bare the Hours, Eunomia, Dice, and blooming Peace, who care for their works for mortal men ;
tgt_text.654: and the Parcæ,5 to whom counselling Jove gave most honour, Clotho, Lachesis, and Atropos, who also give to men good and evil to possess.
tgt_text.655: And Eurynome,6 daughter of Ocean, having a very lovely form, bare him the fair-cheeked Graces, Aglaia, and Euphrosyne, and winsome Thalia;
tgt_text.656: from whose eyelids also as they gazed dropped Love, unnerving limbs, and sweetly too look they under their brows.
tgt_text.657: But he came to the couch of much- nourishing Demeter, who bare him white-armed Proserpine ;
tgt_text.658: er whom Pluto ravished from her mother:
tgt_text.661: And next he was enamoured of beautiful-haired Mnemosyne, of whom were born to him the Muses nine,* with-golden-fillets, to whom festivals, and the delight of song, are wont to be a pleasure.
tgt_text.662: But Apollo and Artemis, rejoicing-in-arrows, a lovely off­ spring beyond all the heavenly-beings, Latona3 in sooth brought forth, after union in love with aegis-bearing Jove.
tgt_text.663: And last made he blooming Juno his spouse.
tgt_text.664: She bare Hebe, and Mars, and Lucina, having been united in love with the king of gods and men.
tgt_text.665: But by himself, from his head, he produced glancing-eyed Tritonis,4 fierce, strife-stirring, army- leading, unsubdued, and awful, to whom dins, and wars, and battles are a delight.
tgt_text.666: And Juno,5 without having been united in love, brought forth famous Vulcan, and put out all her strength, and strove with her husband;
tgt_text.667: Vulcan, distinguished in arts from amongst all the heaven-born.
tgt_text.668: But from Amphitrite and the loud-roaring Earth-shaker sprang great and widely-powerful Triton, who occupies the depth of the sea, and inhabits golden houses1 beside his dear mother and his royal sire, being a terrible god.
tgt_text.669: To shield- piercing Mars, however, Cytherea bare Fear and Terror, formidable deities, even they who route dense phalanxes of men in horrid war, with the help of city-spoiler Mars;
tgt_text.670: 2 and Harmonia, whom high-spirited Cadmus made his spouse.
tgt_text.671: Then to Jove, I wot, Maia,3 daughter of Atlas, bare glori­ ous Hermes, herald of immortals, having ascended his holy couch.
tgt_text.672: And to him, in sooth, Semele,4 daughter of Cadmus, bare an illustrious son, even jocund Bacchus, after union in love, mortal though sce was, an immortal.
tgt_text.674: And Alcmena, after union in love with cloud-com­ pelling Jove, bare Hercules the strong.
tgt_text.675: But Vulcan, far-famed, crippled god, took to wife blooming Aglaia, youngest of the Graces.
tgt_text.676: And Bacchus, of golden hair, took for his blooming bride auburn-tressed Ariadne, daughter of Minos.
tgt_text.677: And her the son of Cronus made im­ mortal, 5 and unsusceptible of old age for him.
tgt_text.678: And fair- ankled Alcmena's valiant son, mighty Hercules, having Be- complished grievous toils, made Hebe, daughter of mighty Jove and Juno-with-golden-sandals, his bashful wife in snowy Olympus:
tgt_text.679: 6 happy hero, who having achieved a great work, dwells among the immortals uninjured and ageless eveimore.
tgt_text.680: To the unwearied Sun the famous Oceanid, Perseis,l bare Circe and king CEetes.
tgt_text.681: And CEetes, son of man-enlightening Sun, wedded beauteous-cheeked Idyia, daughter of Ocean, perfect river, by the will of the gods.
tgt_text.682: But she then, subdued in love through golden Aphrodite, brought forth to him fair-ankled Medea.
tgt_text.683: Now fare ye well, gods dwelling in Olympian mansions ;
tgt_text.684: 2 [Islands and Continents, and briny Sea within ;
tgt_text.685: ] and now Olympian Muses, sweet of speech, daughters of aegis-bearing Jove, sing ye the tribe of goddesses, as many as in truth having been united, though immortal, with mortal men, gave birth to children resembling gods.
tgt_text.686: Ceres, divine among goddesses, after union in delightsome love, bare Plutus to the hero lasius,3 in a thrice-ploughed fal­ low, in the fertile country of Crete, a kind god, who goes over all the earth, and the broad surface of the sea;
tgt_text.687: and to him that has chanced upon him, and into whose hands he may have come, him, I say, he is wont to make rich, and presents to him much wealth.
tgt_text.688: And to Cadmus, Harmonia,5 daughter of golden Aphrodite, bare Ino, Semele, and fair-cheeked Agave, and Autonoe, whom Aristæus of-clustering-locks wedded, and Polydorus in tower-circled Thebes.
tgt_text.689: But Callirhoe, daughter of Ocean, united to brave-hearted Chrysaor in union of all-golden Aphrodite,1 bare a son the strongest of all mortals, Geryon, whom mighty Hercules slew, for the sake of the trailing-footed oxen2 in island Erythea.
tgt_text.690: And to Tithonus Aurora3 bare Memnon with-brazen-helm, king of the Æthiopians, and the sovereign Hemathion.
tgt_text.691: But to Cephalus in truth she produced an illustrious son, the brave Phaethon,4 a man like to the gods, whom, I wot, when young, in the tender flower of glorious youth, a lad, conscious but of young fancies, laughter-loving Aphrodite snatched up, and rushed away, and she made him, in her sacred fanes, her nightly temple-keeper, a divine Genius.
tgt_text.692: And the daughter of (Œtes, Jove-descended king, Jason, 5 son of .:
tgt_text.693: son, by the counsels of ever-living gods, carried off from (Œtes, after he had fulfilled the grievous toils, which, being many in number, the great and overbearing king, insolent and infatuated Pelias, doer of deeds of violence, imposed upon him.
tgt_text.694: Which having achieved, after having toiled much, the son of Æson arrived at Iolchos, bearing in his fleet ship a dark-eyed maiden, and her he made his blooming bride.
tgt_text.695: Yes, and she, having been yoked with Jason, shepherd of his people, bore a son Medeus, whom Chiron, son of Philyra, reared on the mountains;
tgt_text.696: whilst the purpose of mighty Jove was being fulfilled.
tgt_text.697: But of the daughters of Nereus, ancient sea-god, Psamathe in truth, di­ vine among goddesses, bare Phocus 1 in the embrace of Æacus, through golden Aphrodite :
tgt_text.698: and the goddess Thetis, of the sil­ ver feet, yielding to Peleus, gave birth to Achilles the lion- hearted, who-broke-the-ranks-of-men.
tgt_text.699: Fair-wreathed Cytherea2 too, I wot, blending in delight­ some love with the hero Anchises, bare Æneas on the peaks of many-valleyed, woody Ida.
tgt_text.700: But Ciroe, daughter of the Sun, born-of-Hyperion, by the love of Ulysses3 of-enduring- heart, gave birth to Agrius and blameless and strong Latinus ;
tgt_text.701: Telegonus also she bare through golden Aphrodite.
tgt_text.702: Now these in truth very far in a recess of sacred isles,4 reigned over all the very far-renowned Tyrrhenians.
tgt_text.703: But Calypso, divine among goddesses, bore to Ulysses Nausithoüs and Nausinous after union in delightful love.
tgt_text.704: These, though immortal, hav­ ing been united with mortal men, gave birth to children like unto the gods.
tgt_text.705: And now sing ye the tribe of women, ye sweet-spoken Olympian Muses, daughters of ægis-bearing Jove.OR as Alcmena,1 daughter of Electryon,2 exciter of peo­ ples, left her home and father-land, and came to Thebes in the train of martial Amphitryon.
tgt_text.706: She, I wot, excelled the race of gentler women3 in beauty and height;
tgt_text.707: yea, and in mind indeed none did compete with her of those, whom mor­ tal women bare by union with mortal men.
tgt_text.708: Both from her head4 and from her dark eyelids breathed even such a fra­ grance as from those of golden Aphrodite.
tgt_text.709: Yet she e'en so was wont to revere at heart her spouse, as never any of gentler women 1 revered:
tgt_text.710: though in very truth lie had by force subdued and slain her noble father, in wrath about oxen:
tgt_text.711: he then having left his father-land, came to Thebes, and suppli­ cated2 the shield-bearing Cadmeans.
tgt_text.712: There dwelt he with his chaste spouse, apart, and without delightsome union, nor might he ascend the couch of fair-ankled Alcmena, before3 that he bad avenged the slaughter of the high-souled brothers of his wife, and consumed with wasting fire the villages of warlike heroes, the Taphians4 and Teleboans.
tgt_text.713: For so was it ordered him, and the gods were witnesses to it;
tgt_text.714: whose wrath he dreaded, and hastened with all speed to accomplish a great work, which was Jove's law to him.
tgt_text.715: With him then, eager for war and battle-din, the horse-spurring Bœotians, breathing over their shields,5 the close-fighting Locrians, and the high-hearted Phocians, followed, and the gallant son of Alcaeus headed them, glorying in his hosts.
tgt_text.716: But the sire of men and gods was weaving in his mind another counsel, that to gods and inventive6 men he might beget an averter of de­ struction.
tgt_text.717: So he arose from Olympus, building deceit in the deep of his heart, during-the-night, in eagerness for the em­ brace of the fair-zoned dame;
tgt_text.718: and soon he arrived at the Typhaonian height :
tgt_text.719: 7 and thence counsellor Jove drew nigh to topmost Phicium.
tgt_text.720: There sitting be revolved divine works in his mind;
tgt_text.721: for the self-same night he was united in couch and love with the tapering-ankled daughter of Electryon, and he satisfied, I ween, his longing.
tgt_text.722: On the same night too, Amphitryon, rouser of peoples, a splendid hero, returned to his home, after having achieved a great deed.
tgt_text.723: Nor did he hasten to go to his servants, and shepherd hinds,1 that is, be­ fore he had ascended the couch of his spouse:
tgt_text.724: for such eager­ ness possessed the shepherd of his peoples at heart.
tgt_text.725: And as when a man is glad2 to have escaped ill arising out of a severe disease, or even out of hard bonds, so then, I wot, Amphitryon, having brought to an end his difficult task, delightedly and gladly came to his own home.
tgt_text.726: All-night-long3 then he slept beside his modest spouse, delighting himself in the gifts of golden Aphrodite.
tgt_text.727: So then she, embraced by a god and by a man far the best of men, in seven-gated Thebes bare twin sons, agreeing in nought beyond, brothers though indeed4 they were:
tgt_text.728: the one inferior, the other again a far better man, both valiant and strong, the mighty Hercules, whom she bare after having been embraced by the cloud-darkener, son of Cronus:
tgt_text.729: but Iphiclus by Amphitryon, shaker of spears ;
tgt_text.731: 5 the one after union with mortal man, the other with Jupiter, son of Cronus, sovereign of all the gods.
tgt_text.732: Who also slew Cycnus, 6 great-hearted son of Mars :
tgt_text.733: for in the grove of the far-darting Apollo, he found him and his sire Mars, insatiate of war, gleaming in arms, as the brightness of burning fire, upstanding in their chariot:
tgt_text.734: the swift steeds struck the earth, dinting it with their hoofs, and the dust burnt around them, shaken violently beneath wicker1 cars and hoofs of horses.
tgt_text.735: But well-made chariots and seat-rims kept rattling, as the steeds sped on:
tgt_text.736: blameless Cycnus rejoiced, in hope that he should slay with the sword Jove's warlike son, and the charioteer, and strip him of his glorious mail.
tgt_text.737: Yet Phœbus Apollo did not hear his prayers, for he had himself urged the mighty Hercules against him.
tgt_text.738: Then all the grove and altar of Pagasæan 2 Apollo was flash­ ing with the arms of the fearful god, and with himself:
tgt_text.739: and from his eyes fire as it were blazed.
tgt_text.740: Who, being mortal, would have had the courage to rush against him, save Her­ cules and famous lolaus ?
tgt_text.741: for both great strength was theirs, and their unvanquished hands grew3 from their shoulders on stout limbs.
tgt_text.742: Who then, I ween, bespake his charioteer, brave Iolaus:
tgt_text.743: " 0 hero Iolaus,4 far dearest of all mortals, surely some grave sin did Amphitryon sin5 against the blessed immortals, who occupy Olympus, when he left Tiryns,6 well-built city, and came to strongly-fortified Thebes, after having slain Elec­ tryon on the score of the broad-browed herds;
tgt_text.744: and came to Creon, and long-robed Henioche,7 who, I wot, welcomed him, and provided him all things needful,l as 'twas, right they should to suppliants;
tgt_text.745: and they honoured him the more from the heart.
tgt_text.746: So he lived exulting with the beauteous-ankled daughter of Electryon, his spouse:
tgt_text.747: and full soon when the year came round, we were born, thy sire and I, alike neither in stature nor in thoughts.
tgt_text.748: His senses Jove took from him, who left his own hornet and his own parents, and went forth, for the purpose of honouring the erring3 Eurystheus, wretched man that he was;
tgt_text.749: no doubt ofttimes afterward he bewailed over his infatuation, in grief;
tgt_text.750: but it is not to be recalled.
tgt_text.751: On me, however, fate enjoined severe labours.
tgt_text.752: But, my friend, quickly grasp thou now the purple reins of the fleet-footed steeds, and rousing great courage within thy heart, drive4 straight for­ ward the swift chariot, and thy strong fleet-footed steeds;
tgt_text.753: fearing not a whit the din of mortal-slaying Mars, who now is crying out and raging around the sacred grove of Phœbus Apollo, far-darting king:
tgt_text.754: in very truth, mighty though he be, he shall have 5 his fill of war.
tgt_text.755: "And him in turn blameless Iolaus addressed.
tgt_text.756: " Honoured6 lord, in very truth then the sire of gods and men honours thy head, and so does bull-voiced7 Neptune, who keeps the bat- tlement of Thebes, and protects the city;
tgt_text.757: just as now they bring this man also strong and mighty into thy hands, that thou mayest carry off excellent glory.
tgt_text.759: put on thy warlike arms, that, with all speed, having brought our chariots near, that of Mars, and our own, we may engage, since he will not in truth terrify the undaunted son of Jove, nor the child of Iphiclus, but methinks he will flee from the two de­ scendants 1 of the faultless son of Alcæus, who now are nigh to him,2 desiring to engage in the tumult of battle, matters which to them are far more dear than a feast.
tgt_text.761: then smiled the mighty Hercules, exulting 3 in his heart, for he had spoken words very congenial to him, and in answer to him he addressed winged words:
tgt_text.762: " 0 hero Iolaus, Jove-sprung, no more afar is the rough conflict:
tgt_text.763: as then of yore thou wast warlike, so now too guide4 every way the huge steed, dark-maned Arion,5 and aid me as thou mayest be able."
tgt_text.764: So having spoken, he placed about his legs greaves of bright mountain-brass, 6 splendid presents of Vulcan:
tgt_text.765: next donned he a corselet about his breast, beau­ tiful, and of gold, curiously wrought, which Jove's daughter Pallas Minerva had given him, when for the first time he was about to rush furiously upon groanful conflicts.
tgt_text.766: Then fastened the mighty man around his shoulders a sword, the averter of destruction:
tgt_text.767: and the hollow quiver athwart his breast he cast over his back:
tgt_text.768: within it were many chilly arrows, givers of death that-striketh-dumb.
tgt_text.769: At the points indeed they were- fraught with death and were wet with tears, 1 in the middle polished, and very long:
tgt_text.770: but at the back end covered with the feathers of a dusky eaglet
tgt_text.771: Then took he his stout spear, pointed with gleaming brass, and on his strong brows placed his well-wrought, curious helmet of adamant, fitted on his temples, which fenced the head of divine Hercules.
tgt_text.772: Yea, and in his hand he took an all-variegated shield, nei­ ther could any one have broken it by flinging a javelin, nor have shattered it, a marvel to behold.
tgt_text.773: For the whole of it was bright all-around with chalk, and white ivory, and elec­ tron, and gleaming with shining gold;
tgt_text.774: and plates of blue- cast-steel had been drawn across it.
tgt_text.775: On its centre was the unspeakable terror of a dragon glancing backwards with eyes gleaming with fire:
tgt_text.776: his mouth too was filled with teeth run­ ning in a white line,5 dread and unapproachable, and above his terrible forehead, dread Strife was hovering, as she raises the battle-rout:
tgt_text.777: hard-hearted Strife, who, I wot, was taking mind and heart from mortals, whosoever chanced to wage war against the son of Jove.
tgt_text.778: Of these 6 also their souls go be-
tgt_text.779: Death the earth, within the shades, but their bones, when the skin has rotted around them, under the parching Dog-star, 1 moulder in the dark earth.
tgt_text.780: On it had been wrought Driving- forward, and Beating-back, and on it raged Tumult, Fear, and Carnage.
tgt_text.781: Strife too, and Panic, were darting-to-and-fro on it, and2 on it deathly Fate, holding one mortal lately-wounded, another unwounded, and another dead, was dragging them by the feet through the battle-fray.
tgt_text.782: And about her shoulders had she a vestment gory with blood of men, while she looked terribly, and bellowed with the gnashing of teeth.
tgt_text.783: On it like­ wise were heads of terrible serpents, unspeakable, twelve in number, which were wont to scare the races of men upon earth, whosoever chanced to wage war against the son of Jove.
tgt_text.784: From the teeth of which serpents too there was a gnashing, whensoever the descendant of Amphitryon might be fighting.
tgt_text.785: These wondrous works 3 then blazed on the shield.
tgt_text.786: And there appeared4 to the sight as it were spots on the terrible dragons:
tgt_text.787: azure were they on their backs, and they had been blackened as to their jaws.
tgt_text.788: And on it were herds of snouted5 boars and of lions, eyeing one another, and chafing, and ready to spring.
tgt_text.789: Of which also the ranks were advancing in troops, nor in truth did they, either of them, tremble, nay both par­ ties verily were bristling in back.
tgt_text.790: For already before them was lying a huge lion, and around him two boars deprived6 of their life, and their dark blood was dropping down to the ground;
tgt_text.791: while they, letting their necks fall on the ground, lay dead beneath the terrible lions.
tgt_text.792: But they were still the more roused, in rage for fighting, both snouted boars and grim lions.
tgt_text.793: And on it was wrought the battle of the warrior Lapithæ 1 around Cæneus the king and Dryas, and Pirithous, Hopleus, Exadius, Phalerus, and Prolochus, Mopsus, 2 son of Ampyx of Titaressa, a branch of Mars, and Theseus, son of Ægeus, like unto the immortals:
tgt_text.794: these were of silver, having golden arms about their bodies.
tgt_text.795: And the Centaurs3 on the opposite side were gathered together against them, around huge Petræus and Asbolus, diviner-by-birds, Arctus, Urius, dark-haired Mimas, and the two sons of Peucus, Perimedes and Dryalus, in silver likewise, and having in their hands golden pine-trees.
tgt_text.796: Aye and pressing violently 4 together, even as if they were alive, they were fighting hand to hand with outstretched spears and pines.
tgt_text.797: On it too stood in gold the fleet-footed steeds of terrible Mars:
tgt_text.798: and on it likewise destructive Mars himself, the wearer of spoils,5 with lance in hand, cheering his foot­ men,6 empurpled in blood, as if spoiling the living, and stand- ing in his chariot:
tgt_text.799: and beside him stood Terror and Fear,1 eager to enter the war of men.
tgt_text.800: On it too was wrought Jove'a daughter, the Trito-born, driver of spoil, like to her, and as it were wishing to array the battle, having a spear in hand, and a golden helmet,2 and an ægis about her shoulders, and she was approaching the dreadful battle.
tgt_text.801: And on it was a holy choir of immortals;
tgt_text.802: and in the midst, I ween, the son of Jove and Latona was playing a delightsome strain on golden lyre:
tgt_text.803: and holy Olympus,3 seat of the gods:
tgt_text.804: and on it an assembly, but boundless wealth 4 had been wrought encircling it, in a contest of the gods:
tgt_text.805: whilst the goddesses, the Pierian Muses, were beginning the song, like unto clear songstresses.
tgt_text.806: Upon it a harbour too, with safe port, of the monstrous sea, had been fashioned circular-wise of refined tin, like to a surging sea:
tgt_text.807: howbeit many dolphins in the midst of it were dashing here and there in-chase-of-fish, just as though they were swimming:
tgt_text.808: and two dolphins5 of silver, breathing hardly, were feasting-on the dumb fishes.
tgt_text.810: Beneath these were quivering fishes wrought-in-brass:
tgt_text.811: but on the banks sat a fisherman7 on-the-look-out:
tgt_text.812: and he had in his hands a net for fish, resembling as he did one in act to throw.
tgt_text.813: On it too was fair-haired Danae's son, equestrian Perseus:
tgt_text.814: neither, I wot, touching the shield with his feet,1 nor yet far from it, a great marvel to tell of:
tgt_text.816: For so had the famous crippled-god wrought him with his hands in gold, but about his feet he had winged sandals.
tgt_text.817: And around his shoulders a hanger of brass with-iron-scab­ bard lay hanging from a thong:
tgt_text.818: but he was flitting about quick as thought.
tgt_text.820: The whole of his back the head of the Gorgon, terrible monster,3 was covering, and round about it, wrought-in-silver, a knapsack4 was stretching, a marvel to behold, and bright tassels were hanging down wrought-in- gold, and the dreadful helmet of Hades 5 was set around the temples of the king, having a fearful gloom of night.
tgt_text.821: But like unto one hurrying and shuddering with fear, Perseus, son of Danae, himself was outstretched :
tgt_text.822: whilst after him the Gorgons, unapproachable and unspeakable, were darting, ea­ ger to seize him:
tgt_text.823: but as they moved upon the pale adamant,6 the shield seemed clanking with a vast din sharply and shrilly, and on their girdles7 two dragons were hanging, curving their heads.
tgt_text.824: These two, I wot, were forking their tongues, and, looking savagely, were gnashing their teeth in wrath.
tgt_text.825: But over the dread Gorgon heads great terror was shaking:
tgt_text.826: and the men above them were fighting in warlike arms, one party warding off a pest on behalf of their city and their parents, and the other eager to devastate.
tgt_text.828: yet more still were fighting engaged in the conflict:
tgt_text.829: and the women on the well-built towers were shrieking with a brazen shrill­ ness,2 and were tearing their cheeks, like to living women, works of famous Vulcan.
tgt_text.830: But men, who were elders, and whom age had overtaken,3 were in crowds without the gates, and were uplifting their hands to the blessed gods, in fear concerning their children :
tgt_text.831: -these again were engaging in combat, and in their wake the dark Fates,4 gnashing white teeth, of aspect-fierce and terrible, bloody and unapproach­ able, were holding strife for those who fell.
tgt_text.832: But all, I wot, were eager to quaff dark blood:
tgt_text.833: and whom­ soever they had happened to find first lying-low or falling fresh-wounded, about him indeed one of them 5 was casting huge talons, and a soul was descending to Hades, into chill Tartarus.
tgt_text.834: So when they had satisfied their fancy with hu­ man blood, behind them they would cast the corpse, and, go­ ing back again, hurry to the tumult and fray.
tgt_text.835: Clotho and Lachesis stood beside them:
tgt_text.836: the somewhat lesser goddess Atropos' was by no means a tall goddess;
tgt_text.837: but, I ween, she yet was excellent above them all and eldest of them.
tgt_text.838: All of them 2 then had engaged in a sharp conflict about one man, and fiercely looked they one at the other, wrathful in their glances, and on the body they made their nails and hands alike.
tgt_text.839: Beside them too stood Gloomy Bad and dread, pale, squalid, cowering through famine, swollen-of-knee:
tgt_text.840: 4 but long nails were upon the tips of her hands.
tgt_text.841: From her nostrils indeed were flowing mucous discharges, and from her cheeks blood was dripping on the ground:
tgt_text.842: but she stood grinning intolerably,5 and much dust lay upon her shoulders;
tgt_text.843: 6 and moistened was sAe with tears.
tgt_text.844: But hard-by was a city of men with-noble-towers :
tgt_text.845: and seven golden gates fitted in their lintels enclosed it:
tgt_text.846: whilst its men were taking delight in fes­ tivities and dances:
tgt_text.847: for some upon a well-wheeled car were leading home a bride to her husband,7 and the marriage-song was bursting forth unbounded;
tgt_text.848: whilst afar a brilliant gleam from blazing torches was whirling about in the hands of at­ tendant maidens.
tgt_text.849: Now these, blooming in beauty, were going in advance, and sportive bands-of-dancers followed them.
tgt_text.850: These from their soft voices8 were breathing a song to the sound of shrill pipes, and echo around them spread in broken utterance:
tgt_text.851: whilst those to the lyre 1 w ere leading the delight­ some dance.
tgt_text.852: Then again on another side young men were making merry to the sound of the flute :
tgt_text.853: these indeed disporting with dance and song, those on the other hand laughing.
tgt_text.854: But to the flute-player they were proceeding, each of them:
tgt_text.855: and festivals, choirs, and rejoicings were occupying all the city.
tgt_text.856: Others again in front of the city had mounted on horseback and were darting along.
tgt_text.857: And ploughers were cleaving the rich earth, and had their tunics girt neatly.
tgt_text.859: But there was a thick standing-crop.
tgt_text.860: Some on their part indeed were reap­ ing with sharp sickles the staff-like stalks laden with ears, as it were the present of Ceres.3
tgt_text.861: Others, I wot, were binding them in straw-ropes, and were laying the threshing-floor;
tgt_text.862: 4 whilst others with vine-sickles in their hands were gathering- the-fruit of the vines ;
tgt_text.863: others again were carrying to baskets from the vintagers clusters white and dark from tall rows, laden with foliage and silvery tendrils ;
tgt_text.864: and others again were carrying them in baskets:
tgt_text.865: near them was a row-of-vines wrought-in-gold, famous works of very-skilful Vulcan,5 wav­ ing with leaves and trellises6 in-silver, [these again indeed sporting each to the minstrel's flute,] weighed down with grapes:
tgt_text.866: yes, and these indeed had been represented dark.
tgt_text.867: Some were treading 1 the grapes and others were drawing the juice;
tgt_text.868: whilst others were contending with the fist, and in wrestling :
tgt_text.869: 2 others were chasing fleet-footed hares, sportsmen, and a brace of sharp-toothed hounds in front, eager to catch the hares, and they eager to escape them:
tgt_text.870: and beside them horsemen 3 were busy, and for prizes they were engaging in strife and toil:
tgt_text.871: charioteers standing on well-compacted chari­ ots were letting-loose swift steeds, giving them the reins;
tgt_text.872: and the close-joined chariots were flying rattling over the ground, and the naves of the wheels added to the din.
tgt_text.873: They then, I wot, were busied in endless toil, nor had victory ever been achieved for them, but they were engaged in a yet-doubt­ ful contest.
tgt_text.874: Now to them also was proposed a huge tripod, within the course,4 wrought-of-gold, the famous work of skil­ ful Vulcan.
tgt_text.875: Around the rim was flowing Ocean, like as it were swelling;
tgt_text.876: and it was encircling all the curiously-wrought shield.
tgt_text.877: About it the high-hovering swans were clamouring loud, many of which, I wot, were swimming on the water's surface, while near them fishes were tumbling.
tgt_text.878: A marvel to look-upon,6 even to loud-thundering Jove, through whose , counsels Vulcan made the vast and sturdy shield, and framed 1 it with his hands.
tgt_text.879: This was the valiant son of Jove shaking with violence, and vaulting upon his horse-chariot, like unto the lightning-flash 2 of his sire, aegis-bearing Jove, as he lightly took his stand:
tgt_text.880: but for him his brave chariot­ eer, lolaus, mounting the chariot-board, was guiding the crooked car.
tgt_text.881: And nigh them came Minerva, glancing-eyed goddess, and in encouragement addressed them in winged words.“
tgt_text.882: Save you, offspring of Lynceus far-renowned:
tgt_text.883: now of a truth Jove, ruling among the blest, giveth you might to slay Cycnus, and spoil him of his famous arms.
tgt_text.884: But I will tell you 4 one other word, 0 far chiefest among the hosts.
tgt_text.885: Whensoever, I say, you shall have 'reft Cycnus of dear life, there leave him 5 then, and his arms:
tgt_text.886: but do you by yourself watch Mars, the slayer of mortals, as he approaches, where you shall have seen him with your eyes, unprotected by the curiously-wrought shield, and there wound him with sharp blade, and then retire:
tgt_text.887: for look you now, it is not fated for you to capture either his steed or his famous arms.
tgt_text.888: "So spake she, divine among goddesses, and mounted the car6 in haste, bearing in her immortal hands victory and glory.
tgt_text.889: 'Twas then, I wot, Iolaus, Jove-descended, terribly urged on his steeds:
tgt_text.890: and they by reason of his shouting were bearing hurriedly along the swift chariot, raising-a-dust 1 through the plain;
tgt_text.891: for the gleaming-eyed goddess Minerva had inspired them with spirit, by having brandished the ægis;
tgt_text.892: and the earth was groaning around.
tgt_text.893: They then were advancing together, like unto fire2 or a storm, Cycnus, tamer-of-steeds, and Mars, insatiate in the battle-cry.
tgt_text.894: Whose steeds indeed then on facing one an­ other, neighed shrilly :
tgt_text.896: The mighty Hercules addressed him (Cycnus) first.“
tgt_text.897: 0 soft-hearted Cycnus, why now direct ye your swift steeds against us two, men who are experienced in toil and trouble:
tgt_text.898: nay, drive your well-polished chariot outside, and yield to go4 outside of the path.
tgt_text.899: Now look you I pass to Trachis, to the court of King Ceyx ;
tgt_text.900: 5 for in power and reverence he hath pre-eminence at Trachis—and you yourself also know it right well, for you are spouse of his dark-eyed daughter Themistonoe.
tgt_text.901: 0 craven, not assuredly will Mars ward off from you the end of death, that is, if we two shall meet in fight.
tgt_text.902: Already, methinks, even elsewhere, he has made some trial of my lance, when in behalf of sandy Pylos he stood opposed to me, madly desirous for the fight.
tgt_text.903: Thrice indeed stricken by my spear, he supported himself on the earth, his shield having been pierced,6 the fourth time, pressing with all my might, I smote his thigh, and broke-through his huge shield.
tgt_text.904: Then truly had he become dishonoured among im­ mortals, if he had left 1 under my hands his gory trophies.
tgt_text.906: Nor, I ween, was Cycnus, skilled in the spear, minded to restrain his chariot-drawing steeds, in obedi­ ence to the other.
tgt_text.907: Then truly quickly leapt from their well- compacted chariots to the earth both the son of mighty Jove and the son of King Mars.
tgt_text.908: But the charioteers drove near2 their steeds with-flowing-manes:
tgt_text.909: and beneath them, as they rushed on, the broad earth was resounding with feet.
tgt_text.910: Even as when rocks from the lofty top of a high mountain leap- with-a-bound, and fall one upon another:
tgt_text.911: and many oaks of lofty foliage, many pines, and poplars with wide-stretching- roots, are crashed3 by them, as they roll down quickly, till they have reached the plain ;
tgt_text.912: thus fell they one upon another, loudly shouting.
tgt_text.913: Then all the city of the Myrmidons,4 and renowned Iolchus, and Arne, and Helice, and grassy Anthea, echoed loudly with the voice of both.
tgt_text.914: They met together with a wondrous battle-cry;
tgt_text.915: and loudly thundered Jove the counsellor, and down from heaven, I ween, he hurled drops of bloody making that a signal of war to his greatly-daring son.
tgt_text.916: Like as in the glades of a mountain a boar with-jutting- tusks and fierce to look upon, in his spirit ponders upon fight­ ing with hunting men, ay and twisting himself side-ways whets his white tusk, but foam drops about his jaws as he gnashes1 his teeth, and his eyes are like shining fire ;
tgt_text.917: 2 and he bristles with mane erect on his crest and about his neck;
tgt_text.918: like such a beast the son of Jove leapt from his horse-chariot.
tgt_text.919: But when the dusky-winged songster cicala,3 perching on a verdant bough begins to sing of summer for man, the cicala whose meat and drink is the life-giving dew, 4 and both all-day-long, and in-the- morning pours he forth his voice in the fiercest heat, 5 when Si­ rius parches the skin, [then truly the beards spring around the millet, which men sow in summer, when unripe grapes begin to colour, gifts which Bacchus has given to men as matter of joy and grief,] at that season they began to fight, and a great tumult uprose.
tgt_text.920: LAnd as two lions, for a slain buck, in wrath have rushed one on the other, and fierce roaring and gnashing of teeth at the same time arises between them:
tgt_text.921: ] but they, like vultures with curved-talons and hooked-beaks, screaming loudly, fight on a lofty rock for a mountain-roving goat, or a wild stag, a fat one, which a youth has stricken and slain with a shaft from his bow-string, but himself has wandered else- where, being ignorant of the spot;
tgt_text.922: whilst they quickly spy it, and hastily engage in a sharp fight about it;
tgt_text.923: so these heroes rushed, shouting, one on another.
tgt_text.924: Hereupon of a truth Cycnus, eager to slay the son of al­ mighty Jove, drove his brazen lance against his buckler, but broke not through the metal;
tgt_text.925: for the gifts of a god pro­ tected 1 him.
tgt_text.926: But Amphitryon's son, strong Hercules, struck violently with his long spear the neck exposed quickly under­ neath the chin between the helm and shield:
tgt_text.927: and the murder­ ous ashen-beam cleft away the two nerves ;
tgt_text.928: 2 for the vast strength of the hero had fallen on him.
tgt_text.929: Then fell he, as when some oak has fallen,3 or some impassable rock, stricken with the smoking lightning of Jove.
tgt_text.930: So he fell, and around him his curiously-wrought brazen armour rattled.
tgt_text.931: Him then Jove's enduring-hearted son let alone, and he himself watching the approach of Mars, a pest-to-mortals, and looking fiercely with his eyes, like a lion, having chanced on a beast, which very eagerly tears the skin with strong claws, and with all speed deprives it of sweet life, while with fury, I wot, his dark heart is filled:
tgt_text.932: and glaring 5 fearfully with his eyes, and lash­ ing sides and shoulders with his tail, he tears the earth with his feet, nor does any one dare, having seen him face to face, approach or contend with him:
tgt_text.933: such, I ween, stood the son of Amphitryon, insatiate in the battle-cry, in array against Mars, gathering courage in his soul, promptly:
tgt_text.934: but he drew near him grieving in heart, then rushed both, one on the other, with shouting.
tgt_text.935: Yea, as when from a tall jutting-rock a crag has tumbled, and rolls with far boundings, it comes then on impetuously, but a tall hill has stood-in-its-way ;
tgt_text.936: 1 where, in truth, it dashes against it.
tgt_text.938: with just as great a shouting the one namely, chariot-pressing2 destruc­ tive Mars, rushed on with an outcry, but the other quick re­ ceived him.
tgt_text.939: But Minerva, child of aegis-bearing Jove, stood in the way of Mars with the dark ægis, and scowling at him terribly, addressed to him winged words.“
tgt_text.940: Hold, Mars, thy strong spirit, and unconquered hands.
tgt_text.941: For it is not lawful for thee to slay and strip Jove's bold- hearted son, Hercules, of his famous armour.
tgt_text.943: cease from the battle, and oppose not me.
tgt_text.945: yet did she not prevail upon the high-hearted spirit of Mars:
tgt_text.946: but with a great shout, brandishing weapons like unto flame, he quickly rushed on mighty Hercules, in eagerness to slay him :
tgt_text.947: 3 and, in truth, from wrath on account of his dead son, hurled his brazen spear violently against the broad shield.
tgt_text.948: Then glancing-eyed Minerva, stretching her­ self from the chariot, turned off the force of his spear.
tgt_text.950: and having drawn his sharp hanger, he sprang upon stout-hearted Hercules, but the son of Amphi­ tryon, insatiate in terrible war, violently wounded him in his onslaught, when he had exposed his thigh under the curiously wrought shield, and smote strongly through his flesh, having made a thrust with his spear:
tgt_text.951: so he prostrated him to the ground in the midst.
tgt_text.952: Then Terror and Fear 1 drave quickly nigh to him his well-wheeled chariot and steeds, and from the spacious earth placed him in his variously-wrought car:
tgt_text.953: and quickly then they lashed the steeds, and came to vast Olympus.
tgt_text.954: But Alcmena's son and glorious Iolaus, after spoiling Cyc­ nus of the beautiful arms from his shoulders, returned home:
tgt_text.955: and speedily then came they with fleet-footed steeds to the city of Trachis.
tgt_text.956: Glancing-eyed Minerva, however, arrived at vast Olympus, and the halls of her sire.
tgt_text.957: But Cycnus, on the other hand, Ceyx buried, and a countless people,2 who, near the city of the illustrious king, were dwelling in Anthe, and the city of the Myrmidons, and famed Iaolchos, and Arne, and Helice.3
tgt_text.958: And a vast host collected, in honour of Ceyx, dear to the blessed gods.
tgt_text.959: His tomb, however, and monument, the Anaurus4 swept from sight, swelling with wintry rains.
tgt_text.960: For so Apollo, son of Latona, bade it, because, I ween, he was wont to lie in wait, and spoil whoever happened to lead hecatombs to Delphi.
tgt_text.961: This poem of Hesiod is a Didactic poem, having for its main ob­ ject the inculcation of agricultural precepts and the management of domestic matters connected with the farmer's vocation.
tgt_text.962: The latter portion of the work, ήμέϱαι, is a sort of Calendar, while the former, .ἓργα, (by which name alone the whole is sometimes called,) details the whole process of husbandry and country labours.
tgt_text.963: There are two or three episodes, e. g. the story of Pan­ dora, the ages of the world, and the description of winter, (504— 558,) all of which some have thought the work of later poets.
tgt_text.964: Virgil has borrowed much of the ground-work of his Georgics from this poem, which, after his manner, he has admirably worked up, and polished with rare skill.
tgt_text.965: YE Muses1 from Pieria, celebrating in songs, come speak of Jove, and chaunt your2 sire, through whom mortal men are alike famed and fameless, named and nameless, by the will of mighty Jove.
tgt_text.966: For with ease indeed he maketh strong,3 and with ease bringeth low the strong:
tgt_text.967: and easily he minish- eth the illustrious, and increaseth the obscure:
tgt_text.968: easily too doth high-thundering Jove, who dwelleth in mansions highest, straighten the crooked, and blast the proud of heart.
tgt_text.969: Hear and behold and heed, and direct the judgments righteously, 0 thou !1 Now would I narrate what is true, 0 Perses.
tgt_text.970: Not, I ween, was there one kind only of Contention,2 but there are two upon the earth:
tgt_text.971: the one a sensible man would commend, but the other is blameworthy:
tgt_text.972: and they have spirits minded different ways.
tgt_text.974: For the one fosters evil war and discord, cruel as sIte is:
tgt_text.975: her at any rate no mortal loves, but of necessity, by the counsels of the immortals, they honour harsh Strife.
tgt_text.976: The other, however, gloomy Night bare first,4 and her, by far the best, the high-throned son of Cronos, dwell­ ing in the heavens, placed at earth's roots and among men:
tgt_text.977: 'tis sAe also who still rouses a man to work, even though he be inactive.
tgt_text.978: For any one when idle having looked upon an­ other being rich, he,5 I say, makes haste to plough and to plant, and well to order his house;
tgt_text.979: for neighbour rivals neigh­ bour, when hastening toward riches;
tgt_text.980: but this contention is good for mortals.
tgt_text.981: 1 Both potter is jealous of potter, and craftsman of craftsman ;
tgt_text.982: and poor man has a grudge against poor man, and poet against poet.
tgt_text.983: But do thou, Perses,2 lay up these things in thy mind, nor let Contention rejoicing-in-ills hinder thy mind from work, whilst it gapes at strifes, and is a listener in the forum.
tgt_text.985: For rare indeed is the time for contentions and suits-in-the-forum to him, whose substance is not yearly stored up within, in season, substance which Earth bears, the gift of Ceres.
tgt_text.987: When thou hast satisfied thyself with these,5 then, and not till then, further contentions and strife concerning the pos­ sessions of others:
tgt_text.988: but it will never again be allowed you to do thus:
tgt_text.989: let us however forthwith6 put an end to the dispute by righteous judgments which are the best from Jove.
tgt_text.990: For already in sooth have we divided the inheritance, and thou didst carry off much more by plunder:
tgt_text.991: flattering much the bribe-swallowing judges,1 whose will it is to give judgment thus.
tgt_text.993: and they know neither how much half exceeds the whole,2 nor how great advantage is in mallow and as­ phodel.
tgt_text.994: Now3 the gods keep hidden for men their means of sub­ sistence :
tgt_text.995: for else easily mightest thou even in one day have wrought, so that thou shouldest have enough for the year, even though being idle:
tgt_text.996: else straightway wouldst thou lay-by the rudder above the smoker and the labours5 of oxen and of toil-enduring mules would be undone.
tgt_text.997: But Jove in wrath at his heart concealed it, because wily Prometheus6 had beguiled him.
tgt_text.998: Therefore, I ween, he devised baneful cares7 for men.
tgt_text.999: And fire he hid, which indeed the good son of Iapetus stole back for mankind from counsellor Jove in a hollow fennel- stalk, after he had escaped the notice of Jove delighting in the thunderbolt.
tgt_text.1000: Him then cloud-compelling Jove addressed in wrath :
tgt_text.1001: " 0 son of Iapetus, knowing beyond all in counsels, thou exultest in having stolen fire, and deceived my wisdom, a severe woe' to thyself and to men that shall come after.
tgt_text.1002: To them now will I give evil instead of fire, wherewith all may delight themselves at heart, hugging their own evil."
tgt_text.1004: and out-laughed2 the sire of men and gods:
tgt_text.1005: but he bade Vul­ can the illustrious with all speed mix earth with watery and endue it with man's voice and strength, and to liken in coun­ tenance to immortal goddesses the fair, lovely beauty of a maiden:
tgt_text.1006: then he bade Minerva teach her work, to weave the highly wrought web;
tgt_text.1007: and golden Aphrodite to shed around her head grace,4 and painful desire,5 and cares that-waste-the limbs:
tgt_text.1008: but to endue her with a shameless mind6 and tricksy manners he charged the conductor, Argicide Mercury.
tgt_text.1010: but they obeyed Jove, the sovereign son of Cronus:
tgt_text.1011: and forthwith out of the earth the famous crippled- god fashioned one like unto a modest maiden, through the counsels of Jove, the son of Cronus:
tgt_text.1012: and the goddess, gleam­ ing-eyed Minerva, girdled and arrayed her:
tgt_text.1013: and around her skin the goddess Graces and august Persuasion hung golden chains, whilst fair-tressed Hours1 crowned her about with flowers of spring:
tgt_text.1014: and Pallas Minerva adapted every orna­ ment to her person.
tgt_text.1015: But in her breast, I wot, conductor Mercury wrought falsehoods, and wily speeches, and tricksy manners, by the counsels of deep-thundering Jove:
tgt_text.1016: and the herald of the gods placed within her, I ween, a winning voiced and this woman he called Pandora, because all, in­ habiting Olympian mansions, bestowed on her a gift, a mis­ chief to inventive men.
tgt_text.1017: But when he had perfected the dire inextricable snare, father Jove proceeded to send to Epimetheus the famous slayer-of-Argus, swift messenger of the gods, carrying her as a gift:
tgt_text.1018: nor did Epimetheus consider how Prometheus3 had told him never to accept a gift from Olympian Jove, but to send it back, lest haply any ill should arise to mortals.
tgt_text.1019: But he, after receiving it, felt the evil, when now he pos­ sessed it.
tgt_text.1020: Now4 aforetime indeed the races of men were wont to live on the earth apart and free from ills, and without harsh la­ bour, and painful diseases, which have brought death on mor- tali.
tgt_text.1021: [For in wretchedness men presently grow old.]
tgt_text.1022: But5 the woman having with her hands removed the great lid from the vessel, dispersed them:
tgt_text.1023: then contrived she baneful cares for men.
tgt_text.1024: And Hope1 alone there in unbroken abode kept remaining within, beneath the verge of the vessel, nor did it flit forth abroad:
tgt_text.1025: for before that, she had placed-on the lid of the vessel, by the counsels of aegis-bearing, cloud-compeller Jove.
tgt_text.1026: But myriad other ills have roamed forth among men.
tgt_text.1027: For full indeed is earth of woes,2 and full the sea:
tgt_text.1028: and in the day as well as at night diseases unbidden haunt mankind, silently bearing ills3 to men, for counsellor Jove hath taken from them their voice.
tgt_text.1029: Thus not in any way is it possible to escape the will of Jove.4
tgt_text.1030: But if you will, another tale will I briefly-tell you well and skilfully, and do you ponder it in your mind, that from the same origin5 are sprung gods and mortal men.
tgt_text.1031: First-of- all the immortals holding the mansions of Olympus made a golden race of speaking men.
tgt_text.1032: [They indeed were under Cronus,1 what time he ruled in heaven.]
tgt_text.1033: And as gods they were wont to live, with a life void-of-care, apart from, and without labours and trouble:
tgt_text.1034: nor was wretched old age at all impending, but, ever the same in hands and feet, did they de­ light themselves in festivals out of the reach of all ills:
tgt_text.1035: and they died, as if overcome by sleep ;
tgt_text.1037: of-its-own-will the fruitful field would bear them fruity much and ample:
tgt_text.1038: and they gladly used to reap the labours of their hands in quietness along with many good things, being rich in flocks,4 and dear to the blessed gods.
tgt_text.1039: But after that Earth had covered this generation by the bests of mighty Jove, they indeed are daemons,5 kindly, haunting-earth, guardians of mortal men, who, I ween, watch both the decisions of justice, and harsh deeds, going-to-and-fro everywhere over the earth, having wrapt themselves in mist,1 givers of riches as they are:
tgt_text.1040: and this is a kingly function which they have.
tgt_text.1041: Afterwards again the dwellers in Olympian mansions2 formed a second race of silver, far inferior;
tgt_text.1042: like unto the golden neither in shape nor mind:
tgt_text.1043: but for a hundred years 3 indeed a boy was reared and grew up beside his wise mother,4 in hEr house, being quite childish:
tgt_text.1044: but when one happened to come to age and reached the stature of manhood,5 for but a brief space used they to live, suffering griefs through their imprudences:
tgt_text.1045: for they could not keep off rash insult one from the other, nor were they willing to worship the gods, nor to sacrifice6 at the holy altars of the blessed, as it is right men should in their abodes.
tgt_text.1046: Them indeed afterwards, Jove, son of Cronus, buried7 in his wrath, because they gave not due honours to the blessed gods, who occupy Olympus.
tgt_text.1047: Now when earth had ingulfed this race also, they, beneath the ground, are called blessed mortals, second in rank ;
tgt_text.1048: but still honours attends these also.
tgt_text.1049: And yet a third race of speech-gifted men formed father Jove of brass, not at all like unto the silver, formidable and mighty by reason of their ashen-spears:
tgt_text.1050: 1 whose care was the mournful deeds of Mars, and insults:
tgt_text.1051: neither did they at all eat wheaten food only?
tgt_text.1052: but had stout-spirited hearts of ada­ mant;
tgt_text.1054: Now vast force and hands unvan­ quished grew from their shoulders upon sturdy limbs.
tgt_text.1055: These had brazen3 arms, and likewise brazen houses, and with brass they wrought:
tgt_text.1056: for there was not yet dark iron.
tgt_text.1057: They indeed subdued4 beneath their own hands, entered the squalid abode of chilling Hades, inglorious:
tgt_text.1058: for terrible though they were, black Death seized them, and they quitted the bright sun­ light.
tgt_text.1059: But when earth had covered this race also, again Jove, son of Cronus, wrought yet another, a fourth, on the many- nourishing ground, more just and more worthy, a godlike race of hero-men,5 who are called by the former6 age demi- gods over the boundless earth.
tgt_text.1060: And these baneful war, as well as the dire battle-din, destroyed, a part fighting before seven-gated Thebes, in the Cadmean land, for the flocks1 of Œdipus, and part also in ships beyond the vast depths of the sea, when it had led2 them to Troy for fair-haired Helen's sake.
tgt_text.1061: There indeed the end of death enshrouded them;
tgt_text.1062: but to them Jove, the son of Cronus, their sire, having given life and set­ tlements apart from men, made them to dwell at the confines of earth, afar from the immortals.
tgt_text.1064: And they indeed dwell with careless spirit in the Isles of the Blest,3 beside deep-eddying Ocean;
tgt_text.1065: blest heroes, for whom thrice in a year doth the fertile soil bear blooming fruits as-sweet-as-honey.
tgt_text.1067: Would that then I had not mingled with the fifth race of men, but had either died before, or been born afterward.
tgt_text.1069: For now in truth is the iron6 race, neither will they ever cease7 by day, nor at all by night, from toil and wretchedness, cor­ rupt as they are:
tgt_text.1070: but the gods will give them severe cares:
tgt_text.1071: yet nevertheless even for these shall good be mingled with ills.
tgt_text.1072: But Jove will destroy this race also of men endowed with speech, as soon as, immediately after having been born, they become silvery-templed.
tgt_text.1074: Nor will sire be like-minded to sons, nor sons at all to parent, nor guest to host, nor com­ rade to comrade, nor will brother be dear, even as it was aforetime, to brother.
tgt_text.1075: But quickly will they dishonour pa­ rents growing old, and will blame them, I ween, addressing them with harsh words, being impious, and unaware of the vengeance of the gods ;
tgt_text.1076: 2 nor to aged parents would these pay back the price of their nurture, using the right of might:
tgt_text.1077: a and one will sack the city of another:
tgt_text.1078: nor will there be any favour to the trusty, nor the just, nor the good, but rather they will honour a man that doeth evil and is overbearing;
tgt_text.1079: 4 and justice and shame will not be in their hands, and the bad will injure the better man, speaking in perverse speeches, and will swear a false oath.
tgt_text.1080: But on all wretched mortals envy with-its-tongues-of-malice, exulting-in-ills, will attend with hateful look.
tgt_text.1081: Then also in truth to Olympus from earth with-its-broad-ways shall Shame and Retribution, having abandoned men, depart, 1 when they have clad their fair skin in white raiment, to the tribe of the immortals:
tgt_text.1082: but the bane­ ful griefs shall remain behind, and against evil there shall be no resource.
tgt_text.1083: Now then will I speak a fable to kings, wise even though they are.
tgt_text.1084: Thus the hawk addressed the nightingale of varie­ gated-throat, as he carried her in his talons, when he had caught her, very high in the clouds.
tgt_text.1086: 2 pierced on all sides by his crooked talons, was wailing piteously, whilst he victoriously addressed his speech to her. "
tgt_text.1088: 'tis a much stronger that holds thee.
tgt_text.1089: Thou wilt go that way by which I may lead thee, songstress though thou art:
tgt_text.1090: and my supper, if I choose, I shall make, or shall let go.
tgt_text.1091: But4 senseless is he who chooses to contend against them that are stronger, and he is robbed of victory, and suffers griefs in addition to indignities.,,So spake the fleet-flying hawk, broad-pinioned bird.
tgt_text.1092: But do thou, Perses, bear the right, nor help-on wrong :
tgt_text.1093: for wrong is both ill 5 to a poor mortal, nor in truth can a well-to-do man easily bear it, for he is also weighed down by it, having fallen upon the penalties of crime;
tgt_text.1094: 6 the better way is fo arrive at what is right in the contrary path;
tgt_text.1095: and justice surmounts injury, when it has reached to the end.
tgt_text.1096: When he has suf­ fered,1 the senseless man learns this.
tgt_text.1097: For along with crooked judgments straight runs the avenger of perjury;
tgt_text.1098: 2 and a re- listless course is that of Justice, though she be dragged whi- thersoever bribe-swallowing men may lead her, and with perverse judgments deciderupon the existing rights.
tgt_text.1099: And she follows lamenting city and settlements of peoples, clad in mist,3 bringing ill on men, who shall have driven her out, and dis­ pense not a fair decision.
tgt_text.1100: But5 whoso give fair judgments to strangers and to citizens, and do not overstep aught of justice, for these a city blooms, and her peoples flourish within her:
tgt_text.1101: peace rears her young men through the land, nor ever to them doth wide-seeing Jove ordain6 troublous war:
tgt_text.1102: nor ever doth famine, nor ruin, company with men who judge the right, but in festivals they enjoy the fruit of carefully-tended works.
tgt_text.1103: For them bears Earth much substance:
tgt_text.1104: on the mountains the oak7 at its top indeed yields acorns, and midway bees:
tgt_text.1105: the woolly sheep are weighed down with fleeces;
tgt_text.1106: women bear children like unto their sires:
tgt_text.1108: nor ever travel they on board ship ;
tgt_text.1109: 1 but the fertile field yields its increase.
tgt_text.1110: But they, to whom evil, wrong, and hard deeds are a care, to them wide-seeing Jove, the son of Cronus, des.
tgt_text.1112: Oft2 hath even a whole city reaped the evil fruit of a bad man, who sins and puts in practice deeds of infatuation.
tgt_text.1113: On them then from heaven the son of Cronus is wont to bring great calamity, famine and pestilence at the same time:
tgt_text.1115: Neither do the women bear children:
tgt_text.1116: and houses come to nought, by the counsels of Olympian Jove ;
tgt_text.1117: and at other times again the son of Cronus either destroys their wide army, or he lays low their walls,4 or in the deep he punishes their ships.
tgt_text.1118: Now do ye too,5 ye judges, ponder likewise yourselves this vengeance:
tgt_text.1119: for being among men and nigh unto them, the immortals observe as many as with perverse judgments wear- and-waste each other, disregarding the punishment of the:
tgt_text.1121: For on the many-nurturing earth are thrice ten thou­ sand6 immortals, Jove's watchers over mortal men;
tgt_text.1122: who, I weeD, watch both just judgments and daring acts, clad in misty-darkness, and haunting everywhere over the earth.
tgt_text.1123: And Jove's virgin daughter, Justice, besides, is a watcher, illustrious and venerable, with the gods who occupy Olympus.
tgt_text.1124: Yes, and whenever any one wrongs her by perversely railing at her, forthwith taking her seat1 beside Jove, son of Cronus, her sire, she speaks of the unjust mind of mortals, that so the people may atone for the infatuations of kings,2 who, with pernicious intents, turn her the wrong way by speaking judg­ ments perversely.
tgt_text.1125: Heeding these things, ye judges, swallow- ers-of-the-bribe, make straight your sentiments, and entirely forget crooked judgments.
tgt_text.1126: For himself doth a man work evil, in working evils for another, and the evil counsel is worst to him that hath devised it.
