tgt_text.1128: Jove's eye, having seen all things, and observed all things, also regards these things, if he so please, nor does it escape him, of what nature, in truth, is this justice,4 which the city encloses within.
tgt_text.1129: Now might in truth neither I myself, nor my son, be just among men, since to be a just man is an evil, if so be that the more unjust man is to have the stronger justice.
tgt_text.1130: But this I hope that Jove, delighting in thunders, will not yet bring about.
tgt_text.1131: 5Yet, 0 Perses, do thou ponder these things in thine heart, and heed justice in sooth, and forget violence entirely.
tgt_text.1132: For this law hath the son of Cronus ordained for men,6 for fishes indeed and beasts, and winged fowls to eat each other, since justice is not among them:
tgt_text.1133: but to men hath he given justice, which is far best.
tgt_text.1134: For if a man choose to know and speak out what is just, to him also wide-seeing Jove gives felicity;
tgt_text.1135: but whoso in his testimony, wilfully having sworn a false oath, 1 shall have lied, and by it having marred justice, shall have gone astray incurably, of him then the race is left more ob­ scure for the future.
tgt_text.1136: Of a man, however, of-true-oath, the generation is more excellent thereafter.
tgt_text.1138: Now will I speak to thee with good intent, thou exceeding foolish Perses.
tgt_text.1139: Badness,3 look you, you may choose easily in a heap:
tgt_text.1140: level is the path, and right near it dwells.
tgt_text.1141: But before virtue the immortal gods have set exertion :
tgt_text.1142: and long and steep and rugged at the first is the way to it,4 but when one shall have reached the summit, then truly it is easy, dif­ ficult though it be before.
tgt_text.1143: This man, indeed, is far-best,5 who shall have understood everything for himself, after having devised what may be best afterward and unto the end:
tgt_text.1144: and good again is he likewise who shall have complied with one advising him well:
tgt_text.1145: but whoso neither himself hath understanding, nor when he hears another, lays it to heart, he on the other hand is a worth­ less man.
tgt_text.1146: Do thou then, ever mindful of my precept, work- on, Perses, of stock divine,' that so famine may hate, and fair-chapleted Demeter love thee, august as she is, and fill' thy garner with substance.
tgt_text.1147: For famine, look you, is ever the sluggard's companion.
tgt_text.1148: And with him gods and men are indignant, who lives a sluggard's life, like in temper to stingless drones,2 which lazily consume the labour of bees, by devouring it:
tgt_text.1149: but to thee let it be a pleasure3 to set in order seemly works, that so thy garners may be full of seasonable substance.
tgt_text.1150: From works men become both rich-in-flocks and wealthy:
tgt_text.1151: by working too, thou wilt be dearer far to immortals and to mortals.
tgt_text.1152: For greatly do they hate sluggards.
tgt_text.1155: And if thou shouldst work, quickly will the sluggard envy thee growing rich;
tgt_text.1156: for esteem and glory accompany wealth.
tgt_text.1158: So to a sensible man,5 such as thou wert, to labour is best, if having turned a witless mind from the possessions of others towards work, thou wouldst study.
tgt_text.1159: thy subsistence, as I recommend thee.
tgt_text.1160: But a false shame possesses a needy man, shame6 which greatly hurts or helps men.
tgt_text.1161: Shame, look you, is beside wretchedness, but confidence beside wealth;
tgt_text.1162: and possessions not gotten-by-plunder, but given-by-the-gods, are far best.
tgt_text.1163: For if any one even with his hands shall have taken great wealth by violence, or if he for his part shall have plundered it by his tongue, even as often happens, as soon as in truth gain hath deceived the minds of men, and shamelessness comes suddenly on shame, then,2 I say, easily do the gods darken his name:
tgt_text.1164: the family of such a man is minished, and but for a brief space doth his wealth accompany him.
tgt_text.1165: And alike he who shall have done evil to suppliant and to guest, and he who mounts the couch of his kinsman, for stealthy union3 with his wife, doing acts unseemly ;
tgt_text.1166: and whoso through the senselessness of any one wrongs orphan children, and whoso reproaches an aged parent on the threshold of wretched age, assailing him with severe words ;
tgt_text.1167: against such an one, I say in truth, Jove himself is wroth,4 and at the last, in requital for wrong deeds, lays on him a bitter penalty.
tgt_text.1168: Then keep thou wholly a witless mind from these deeds.
tgt_text.1169: But after thy power do sacrifice to the immortal gods,5 holily and purely, and burn moreover sleek thighs of victims, and at ther times propitiate them with libations, and incense, both when you go to rest, and when the holy light shall have risen:
tgt_text.1170: that so to thee they may entertain a propitious heart and spirit, that thou mayest buy the land of others, not others thine.
tgt_text.1171: Invite the man that loves thee to a feast,1but let alone thine enemy:
tgt_text.1172: and especially invite him that dwelleth near thee:
tgt_text.1173: for if, mark you, anything strange shall have happened at hornet neighbours are wont to come ungirt, but kinsfolk gird themselves first.
tgt_text.1174: A bad neighbour is as great a misfortune as a good one is a great blessing.
tgt_text.1176: Who gains a worthy neigh­ bour, hath truly gained a meed of honour:
tgt_text.1177: neither would an ox perish, if there were not a bad neighbour.
tgt_text.1179: Duly measure when thou borrowest from a neighbour, and duly repay, in the very measure, and better still, if thou canst,5 that so when in want thou mayest find that which may be relied on in future.
tgt_text.1181: base gains are equal to losses.
tgt_text.1183: and be nigh him that attaches himself to thee:
tgt_text.1184: and give to him who may have given:
tgt_text.1185: give not to him that hath not given.
tgt_text.1186: To a giver on the one hand some have given :
tgt_text.1187: but to the withholder none give.
tgt_text.1189: but plunder6 evil,—a dealer of death.
tgt_text.1190: For whatsoever man shall have given willingly,1 he too would give much.
tgt_text.1192: in his gift, and is pleased in his spirit.
tgt_text.1193: But whoso shall have seized, in compliance with his shamelessness, even though it be but a little, yet that little curdles his heart's blood.
tgt_text.1195: For if thou shouldst lay up even a little upon a little, and shouldst do this often, soon would even this become great.
tgt_text.1196: He who brings, in addition to what is in store, this man shall escape dark hunger:
tgt_text.1197: nor does that at least which is laid up in the house distress a man.
tgt_text.1198: Better is it that it should be at home, since that which is without is attended with loss.
tgt_text.1200: 'Tis good to take from what is at hand, but a woe to the spirit to want of that which is far from you:
tgt_text.1201: which truths I bid thee pon­ der.
tgt_text.1202: At the beginning too of the cask, and at the end, take thy fill, but spare it in the middle:
tgt_text.1203: 4 for sparingness is too late at the bottom.
tgt_text.1204: Let the recompence fixed for a friend be suf­ ficient, and, as in sport, with a brother even call in witnesses :
tgt_text.1205: 5 for trust, I wot, look you, as well as mistrusts, has ruined men.
tgt_text.1206: Nor let a woman with sweeping train1 beguile tby mind, winningly coaxing, and seeking after thy dwelling:
tgt_text.1207: for who trusts a woman, that man, I wot, trusts knaves.
tgt_text.1209: And let there be one only-son to tend his father's house:
tgt_text.1210: 3 for so shall wealth increase in the dwelling.
tgt_text.1211: But if old, you may die and leave another son.
tgt_text.1212: For easily to more might Jove provide vast wealth.
tgt_text.1213: For of many greater is the care, and greater the gain.
tgt_text.1214: Now if thy spirit desires wealth in thy mind, thus do, and moreover do work upon work.
tgt_text.1215: When the Pleiads, born-of-Atlas, rise, begin thy harvest;
tgt_text.1216: but thy ploughing, when they set.
tgt_text.1218: Now these, look you, are hidden for forty nights and days;
tgt_text.1219: 5 and again in revolving years they appear when first the sickle is sharpened.
tgt_text.1220: This truly is the law of fields, as well for them who dwell near the sea, as for those who inhabit wooded valleys, a fertile soil afar from the swelling sea:
tgt_text.1221: 1 sow stript, plough stript, and reap stript, if thou shouldst wish to gather the works Ceres, all in their seasons, that so each may grow for thee in flue time, lest in anywise, being in need meanwhile, thou shouldst go begging to other people's houses, and accomplish nothing.
tgt_text.1223: As e'en now thou hast come to me ;
tgt_text.1224: but I will not add more to thee, nor measure out4 aught in addition:
tgt_text.1225: work, senseless Perses, the works which the gods have destined for mortal,,;
tgt_text.1226: , lest ever, with children and wife grieving thine heart, thou shouldst seek thy subsistence among neighbours, and they should neglect thee.
tgt_text.1227: For twice indeed or thrice perhaps thou wilt obtain, but if thou trouble them further, thou shalt avail nought, but wilt speak many words in vain :
tgt_text.1228: and use­ less will be thy range of words.
tgt_text.1230: I recommend thee then to study both payment of debts, and avoidance of hunger.
tgt_text.1231: First of all get a house, and a woman, and a ploughing ox;
tgt_text.1232: a wo­ man purchased, not wedded,6 who may also tend your cattle, and all fitting implements in your house, lest you should ask of another, and he refuse, and you be in want of it, so the season should pass by, and your labour's fruit be lessened Nor put off till to-morrow or the-day-after;
tgt_text.1233: for not, if he works-sluggishly or puts off, doth a man fill his garner:
tgt_text.1234: but diligence increaseth the fruit of toil.
tgt_text.1236: A dilatory man ever wrestles with losses.
tgt_text.1237: 2When now the violence of the keen sun abates his sweat- causing heat, as all-powerful Jove rains in-the-autumnal-sea­ son, and the body of man moves itself far more lightly,3 for at this season in truth the star Sirius4 comes in the day-time for a short space above the heads of men born-to-death, but has more share of the night ;
tgt_text.1238: then is the timber least worm- eaten,5 if felled with the axe, and sheds its leaves on the ground, and ceases from budding;
tgt_text.1239: then truly, bearing it in mind, fell a timely work.
tgt_text.1241: Hew a mortar7 three feet in diameter, and a pestle three cubits, and an axle-tree seven feet long, for, look you, it is very serviceable thus;
tgt_text.1242: but if you should cleave it eight feet, you might also cut from it a mal­ let.
tgt_text.1244: And hew a wheel three spans long for the plough-car­ riage of-ten-palms'-length.
tgt_text.1246: Many curved blocks of seasoned wood are at hand;
tgt_text.1247: but bring your plough-tail home, when you shall have found it, after search on mountain or in field,2 of ilex-oak:
tgt_text.1248: for this is stoutest for steers to plough;
tgt_text.1249: when­ soever a servant of Minerva,3 having fastened it to the share- beam, has attached it with nails, and fitted it to the pole.
tgt_text.1250: But make two ploughs,4 toiling at them at home, one with plough-tail of one-piece with the share-beam, the other com­ pacted, for 'tis much better thus, if, look you, you should have broken one, you might place the other upon the oxen:
tgt_text.1251: and poles are soundest5 of bay or elm:
tgt_text.1252: but provide yourself a share-beam of oak, a plough-tail of ilex-oak, and a pair of males, steers nine-years-old, (for the vigour of such is not weak,) having the just mean of age, which are best for working.
tgt_text.1253: Such at least would not strive in the furrow and break the plough, and leave there their labour unfinished.
tgt_text.1254: And along with these let a lusty ploughman of forty years follow, having made a meal on a loaf four-squared, divided into eight morsels,1 who, minding his business, will cut the furrow straight,2 no longer peering round among his fellows, but having his heart in his work;
tgt_text.1255: than such an one none other, being younger, is better to disperse the seed,3 and to avoid after-sowing.
tgt_text.1256: For a younger man gapes like one dis­ traught after his fellows.
tgt_text.1257: Mark, too, when from on high out of the clouds you shall have heard the voice of the crane4 uttering its yearly cry, which both brings the signal for ploughing, and points the season of rainy winter, but gnaws the heart of the man that hath no oxen:
tgt_text.1258: then truly feed the crumpled-horned oxen re­ maining within their stalls:
tgt_text.1259: for it is easy to say the word, " Lend me a yoke of oxen, and a wain but easy is it to re­ fuse, saying, There is work for my oxen.
tgt_text.1261: Then thinks the man, rich in his own conceit,6 to build a wain, fool as he is, nor knows he this, “ but there are also a hundred planks to a waggon,” 1 for which it is meet first to take thought, to get them within the house.
tgt_text.1262: But when first the season of ploughing has appeared to mortals, even then rouse thyself, thy servants alike and thy­ self, ploughing during the season of ploughing, whether dry or wet, hasting very early, that so thy corn-lands may be full.
tgt_text.1263: In spring torn up the soil and the ground tilled afresh in summer will not mock thy hopes:
tgt_text.1264: and sow thy fallow-land while yet light.
tgt_text.1265: Fallow-land is a guardian-from-death-and- ruin, and a soother of children.
tgt_text.1267: Make vows, too, to in fernal, and chaste Demeter 4 that they may load the ripe holy seed-corn of Demeter, when first beginning thy ploughing, when thou hast taken in hand the goad at the extremity of the plough-tail, and touched the back5 of the oxen dragging the oaken peg of the pole with the leathern strap :
tgt_text.1268: 6 and let the servant boy behind, carrying a mattock, cause trouble to birds,.
tgt_text.1269: whilst he covers over the seed.
tgt_text.1270: For good-management is best to mortal men, and bad-management worst.
tgt_text.1271: Thus, if the Olympian god himself afterwards give a prosperous end, will the ears bend to the earth with fulness, and thou wilt drive the cobwebs from the bins,2 and I hope that thou wilt rejoice, taking-for-thyself from substance existing within.
tgt_text.1273: And in plenty thou wilt come to the white spring, nor wilt thou gaze on others, but another man will be in want from you.
tgt_text.1274: But if at the point of mid-winter4 you shall have ploughed the divine earth, you will have to sit and reap but little, grasping what meets your hand, being covered with dust as you tie it up, not much to your pleasure;
tgt_text.1275: and you will carry it in a basket, while few will eye you with admiration.
tgt_text.1277: Now di­ verse at divers seasons is the purpose of Jove, and hard for mortal men to understand.
tgt_text.1278: But if you shall have ploughed late, this would be your remedy:
tgt_text.1279: When the cuckoo sings first on the oak-foliage, and delights mortals over the boundless earth, then let Jove rain three days, 1 and not cease, neither over-topping your ox's hoof-print nor falling short of it:
tgt_text.1280: * thus would a late-plougher be-equal-with an early one.
tgt_text.1281: But duly observe all things in your mind, nor let either the spring becoming white with blossoms, or the showers returning-at- set-seasons, escape your notice.
tgt_text.1282: But pass-by the seat at the brazier's forge,3 and the warm lodging-house in the winter season, when cold keeps men from toils;
tgt_text.1283: at which time an active man4 would greatly improve his household matters;
tgt_text.1284: lest the hardship of baneful winter along with poverty catch thee, and with lean hand thou press a swollen foot.
tgt_text.1286: But many ill designs hath the idler, waiting for a vain hope, and in need of subsistence, spoken in his spirit.
tgt_text.1287: And 'tis no good hope that sustains a needy man, sitting at a lodging-house, and who hath not means-of-life sufficient.
tgt_text.1288: Point out, then, to thy servants,6 when it is still mid-summer, " It will not be summer alway:
tgt_text.1290: "But the month Lenæon, 1 (evil days, all galling the oxen,) this month avoid, and the hoar frosts, which, when the North- wind blows, are hard upon the earth:
tgt_text.1291: the North-wind, which sweeping through steed-rearing Thrace,2 upon the broad deep, is wont to heave it, and land and forest re-echoes:
tgt_text.1292: 3 and falling on them, brings to many-feeding earth many lofty- foliaged oaks, and branching pines in the mountain-dells, so then all the immense forest resounds.
tgt_text.1294: The wild-beasts cower, and place their tails beneath their legs, though their skin is covered over with hair:
tgt_text.1295: yet even through these, chilly as it is, the North-wind pierces, even though they are shaggy- breasted.
tgt_text.1296: It goes also through the hide of an ox, nor does that keep it out, ay, and blows through the shin of the long- haired goat;
tgt_text.1297: but flocks of sheep, because their fleeces last a whole year,5 the violence of the North-wind does not at all penetrate;
tgt_text.1298: but it makes the old man bent."
tgt_text.1300: And through the soft-skinned maiden it does not pierce, 1 who bides within the house beside her dear mother, as yet inexperienced in the deeds of golden Aphrodite ;
tgt_text.1301: when, having bathed her tender form, and anointed herself with rich oil, she shall rest during the night within the house in the wintry season, when the boneless one (the polypus) gnaws at his own foot, in an abode without fire, and in dismal haunts.
tgt_text.1302: For the Sun doth not show him a feeding-range 4 to assail:
tgt_text.1303: but turns toward the nation and city of tawny men, and more slowly shines on the Panhellenes.
tgt_text.1305: Then at length the horned and unhorned tenants of the wood, sorely grinding their teeth, fly up and down the woodland thickets, (and this is the care of all of them in their thoughts,) where seeking a shelter they have thick-covered lairs and rocky caves:
tgt_text.1306: then truly are they like to a man that-goes-on-a-stick,6 whose back is well-nigh broken, and head looks toward the ground:
tgt_text.1307: like such an one they roam, shunning the white snow.
tgt_text.1308: Even then, as I bid you, clothe yourself in a defence for your body, 1 a soft cloak, and a frock reaching to the ground;
tgt_text.1309: and into a scant warp weave an abundant woof:
tgt_text.1310: this cast around you, that your hairs may not shiver, nor bristle raised erect about your body.
tgt_text.1312: And about your feet bind suitable sandals of the hide of an ox slaughtered with your mighty having covered them thick within with felt.
tgt_text.1313: Then, when the season of cold has come, stitch together with the sinew of an ox the skins of first-born kids, that so upon your back you may throw a shelter from the rain;
tgt_text.1314: and on the head above keep a well-wrought felt hat, that you may not get your ears drenched.
tgt_text.1315: For bleak both Is the morn, when the North-wind falls upon one,4 and in-the-morning over the earth from the starry heaven a wheat-bringing mist is spread above the till­ age of the rich,5 a mist which also having drawn water for itself from ever-flowing streams, and borne high above the earth by a storm of wind, one while indeed rains toward evening, and at another descends-in-blasts, the Thracian North-wind driving the dense clouds.
tgt_text.1317: Anticipating this, return home, when you have finished work, lest ever a-dark cloud from the sky should surround you, and drench your skin, and soak your garments;
tgt_text.1319: for this win­ try month 1 is most severe, severe to flocks, 2 and severe to men.
tgt_text.1320: Then to oxen give but half, but let man have a larger share, of the allotted food,3 for long nights are great helpers.
tgt_text.1321: Observing these things to the completion of the year, equalize the allowance nights and days, until again Earth, the mother of all, has put forth her various fruits.
tgt_text.1322: 4But when after the winter solstice Jove hath fulfilled sixty days of-winter,5 even then it is that the star Arcturus, having left the sacred stream of Ocean, first rises brightly beaming in-the-twilight.
tgt_text.1323: After him is wont to rise Pandion's daugh­ ter, the swallow with-its-plaint-at-dawn,6 for a light to men, when spring is fresh-beginning.
tgt_text.1326: When, moreover, the snail climbs up the plants from-off the ground, shunning the Pleiads, then His no longer the season for hoeing the vines:
tgt_text.1327: but you should sharpen sickles, and rouse your servants.
tgt_text.1328: Fly shady seats and sleep at-morn­ ing-time,2 at harvest-season when the Sun parches the skin.
tgt_text.1329: Then make you haste, gather-and-bring home your corn, rising at the dawn, that you may have substance sufficient.
tgt_text.1330: For the morning obtains by lot a third share of the day's work:
tgt_text.1331: The morn, look you, furthers a man on his road, and furthers hint too in his work;
tgt_text.1332: the morn, I say, which, at its appearing, sets many men on their road, and places the yoke on many oxen.
tgt_text.1333: When the artichoke flowers,3 and the tuneful cicala, perched on a tree, pours forth a shrill song oft-times from under his wings, in the season of toilsome summer, then goats are fat­ test, wine is best, women most wanton, and men weakest,4 since Sirius parches head and knees, and body also is dried- up by reason of heat.
tgt_text.1334: But then at last be thine the rocky shade, and Biblian wine,5 a light-well-baked cake, the milk of goats which-are-now-off-their milk,1 and the flesh of a heifer browsing-the-forest, which has not yet calved,2 and of first- born kids-then sit in the shade, and drink moreover dark- hued wine, (having your soul satisfied with viands, and turning your face to catch the brisk-blowing Zephyr,) 3 and the ever-running and forth-gushing spring, which is untroubled- by-mud.
tgt_text.1335: Pour in three cups of water first, and add the fourth of wine.
tgt_text.1336: 4Urge your servants, too, to thrash the holy gift of Demeter, when first Orion's strength5 shall have appeared, in a breezy place, and on a well-rounded thrashing-floor:
tgt_text.1337: and by measure store it well in bins.
tgt_text.1338: But when at length you have laid up all your substance, duly prepared within your house, I re­ commend you to get a houseless hireling,6 and to seek a female servant without children:
tgt_text.1339: for a female-servant with children is troublesome.
tgt_text.1341: 7 stini not his food lest ever a day-slumbering man shall have plundered thy property.
tgt_text.1342: Gather in hay and litter, 1 that your oxen and mules may have fodder for the year.
tgt_text.1343: Afterwards refresh the limbs of your servants, and unyoke your pair of oxen.
tgt_text.1344: But when Orion and Sirius shall have reached mid-heaven, and rosy-fingered Aurora looked on Arcturus,2 then, Perses, cull and carry home all thy grape-clusters.
tgt_text.1345: Then expose them to the Sun3 ten days and ten nights, shade them five days, and on the sixth draw into vats the gifts of joyous Bac­ chus.
tgt_text.1346: But when now the Pleiads, Hyads,4 and strong Orion set, then be thou mindful of ploughing in due season.
tgt_text.1347: And may the year5 be prosperous to thee in thy rustic matters.
tgt_text.1348: But if a longing for dangerous6 voyaging seizes you, when fleeing the impetuous might of Orion, the Pleiads sink into the misty deep,7 then rage the blasts of winds of every de- scription:
tgt_text.1349: then also keep no more your ships on the dark sea, but remember to till your land, as I recommend you.
tgt_text.1350: Haul ashore your ship, and cover-it-thick with stones on all sides, 1 that they may keep off the violence of moist-blowing winds, when you have drawn out the keel-plug, that Jove's rain may not rot it.
tgt_text.1351: Store away in your house all the ship's tackle 2 duly arranged, and furl in good order the sails of your deep- skimming bark, and hang up above the smoke your well- wrought rudder.
tgt_text.1352: And wait you for a passage in due season, until it shall have come:
tgt_text.1353: then drag down to the sea your swift ship, and store in it also a prepared freight, that so you may bring home gain, even as my sire and yours,3 very sense­ less Perses, used to sail in ships, in search for honest sub­ stance :
tgt_text.1354: who of old came hither too, when he had traversed much sea, after having left Cuma in Æolia, in dark ship;
tgt_text.1355: forsaking nor plenty, nor riches and wealth, but evil poverty, which Jove gives to men.
tgt_text.1356: Near Helicon he dwelt in Ascra, a wretched hamlet, bad in winter, oppressive in summer, and never genial.:
tgt_text.1357: But thou, Perses, be thou mindful of all works in-their- seasons, and most of all about navigation.
tgt_text.1359: 1 in a large one stow thy freight.
tgt_text.1360: Greater will be thy cargo, and greater thy gain upon gain, that is to say, if the winds keep off evil blasts.
tgt_text.1361: When thou shalt have turned thy silly mind towards merchandise, and desired to escape debts and unpleasant hunger,2 then will I show thee the courses3 of the loud-roaring sea, though neither at all clever in navigation, nor in ships.
tgt_text.1362: For never yet have I sailed in ship, at least across the broad deep, save to Eubœa from Aulis,4 where formerly the Greeks, having waited through the winter, collected together a vast host from sacred Greece 5 for Troy with-its-beauteous women.
tgt_text.1363: And there I crossed over to the games in honour of warlike Amphidamas6 and to Chalcis :
tgt_text.1364: the numerous prizes duly proclaimed his noble- spirited sons had set up:
tgt_text.1365: there boast I that, as victor in the lay, I carried off an eared tripod.
tgt_text.1366: This I offered to the Muses of Helicon, where 1 first they initiated me in the tuneful song.
tgt_text.1367: Thus much experience only have I had in ships with-many-nails:
tgt_text.1368: but even so I will speak the mind of aegis-bearing Jove:
tgt_text.1369: for the Muses have taught me to sing the divine song.
tgt_text.1371: For fifty days after the summer solstice,3 when summer, a season of toil, has come to an end, sailing is seasonable for mortals:
tgt_text.1372: neither then would you founder your ship, nor would the sea destroy the crew, unless, that is, of-set-purpose, earth-shaking Neptune, or Jove, king of immortals, should choose to destroy them:
tgt_text.1373: for with them is the end of good and bad alike.
tgt_text.1374: But at that season the breezes are clear,4 and the deep free-from-danger:
tgt_text.1375: then in security, relying on the winds, drag down to sea your swift ship, and duly stow in it all the cargo:
tgt_text.1376: but hasten with all speed to come back home;
tgt_text.1377: wait not the new wine, and au­ tumn rain,5 the coming winter, and the terrible blasts of the South-wind, which is wont to disturb the sea, when it fol­ lows Jove's abundant rain, in autumn, and renders the deep dangerous.
tgt_text.1378: Another season of sailing, amongst men, is in the spring.
tgt_text.1380: When in truth at the first, as large as the crow, advancing, has left her foot-print, just so large leaves will appear to a man on the top of the fig tree's branch, then, I say, the sea may be traversed ;
tgt_text.1381: but this is a spring voyaged I praise it not, for it is not pleasant to my thinking, because snatched in haste:
tgt_text.1382: 3 with difficulty could one avoid evil;
tgt_text.1383: yet even this too men do, through foolishness of mind:
tgt_text.1384: for riches are life to wretched mortals.
tgt_text.1386: But dreadful it is to die in the waves:
tgt_text.1387: now thee I recommend to consider all these things in thy mind, as I speak them.
tgt_text.1388: Nor do thou stow all thy substance in hollow ships, but leave most behind, and make the lesser share thy cargo.
tgt_text.1389: For shocking it is to meet with loss in the waves of the sea;
tgt_text.1390: and sad, if when thou hast lifted an ex­ cessive weight on thy waggon, thou crush the axle, and the loads be wasted.
tgt_text.1392: In all the fitting- season is best.
tgt_text.1393: -And at mature age bring home a wife to thine house, when thou art neither very far short of thirty years,6 nor hast added very much thereto, for such a marriage, look you, is seasonable.
tgt_text.1394: And let the woman be in her bloom four years, and be married in the fifth.
tgt_text.1396: Marry a maiden, too, that you may teach her chaste morals.
tgt_text.1397: Most of all, marry her who lives near you, when you have duly looked round on everything, lest you should marry a cause-of-mocking 2 for your neighbours.
tgt_text.1398: For nothing better does a man gain than the good wife, whilst than the worse, the banquet-seeker, nought else is more dreadful:
tgt_text.1399: though a man be strong, she consumes him without a torch,3 and consigns him to unripe old age.
tgt_text.1400: And be duly regardful of the vengeance of the blest Im­ mortals :
tgt_text.1401: neither make thy friend equal to a brother:
tgt_text.1402: but, if thou shalt have made him so, be not the first to do him wrong;
tgt_text.1403: and lie not, for talking's sake ;
tgt_text.1404: 4 though, if he should begin either to speak aught distasteful, 5 or even to do it against you, requite him just twice as much, in thy resentment;
tgt_text.1405: but if again he lead the way to friendship, and be willing to give satisfaction, accept it;
tgt_text.1406: it is a wretched man, be sure, that gets now one, now another for his friend,6 but thy mind let not thy countenance at all convict.
tgt_text.1407: Neither be called the host of many, nor the host of none, nor comrade of the evil, nor re­ viler of the good.
tgt_text.1408: Nor ever have-the-cruelty to reproach a man with wretched, heart-consuming poverty,1 the behest of the ever-living gods.
tgt_text.1409: The best treasure, look you, among men is that of a sparing tongue,2 and the most grace is that of one which moves measuredly.
tgt_text.1410: If you have spoken ill, haply you will yourself hear worse.
tgt_text.1411: Neither be uncourteous in a feast of many guests, arising from a general payment:
tgt_text.1412: 3 for the pleasure is then greatest, the expense least.
tgt_text.1413: Nor ever in the morning make libations of dark wine to Jove with hands unwashen,4 nor to the other gods.
tgt_text.1414: For they on their part heed not, and more, they spurn your prayers.
tgt_text.1415: Neither do thou ever cross the limpid wave of ever-flowing rivers5 with thy feet, that is, before thou shalt have prayed, gazing on the fair streams, and having thine hands wash en with the pleasant clear water.
tgt_text.1416: Whoso shall have crossed a river having his hands unwashen through perverseness, with him the gods are wroth, and are wont to give him griefs after­ ward.
tgt_text.1417: And do not at a festive banquet of the gods pare from the finger6 with bright steel the dry from the fresh.
tgt_text.1418: Nor ever place a can above the bowl, when men drink:
tgt_text.1419: 1 for a deadly fate is wrought in it.
tgt_text.1420: Nor, when building a house, leave it not-finished-off, lest, mark you, perching on it, the cawing crow should croak.
tgt_text.1422: Nor, having taken from cauldrons not-yet-used-for-sacrifice, eat, or wash thyself:
tgt_text.1423: since in these, too, there is a penalty.
tgt_text.1424: Nor let a lad of twelve years sit inactively;
tgt_text.1425: 3 for 'tis better not, since it makes a man unmanly:
tgt_text.1426: nor yet a child of twelve months;
tgt_text.1427: for this is all the same.
tgt_text.1428: Nor, being a man, cleanse thy skin in the woman's bath ;
tgt_text.1429: for on this, too, there is a dismal penalty for a time.
tgt_text.1430: Nor, if thou hast chanced upon lighted sacrifices, mock at rites of hid­ den import ;
tgt_text.1431: 4 the god, look thou, is wroth at this also.
tgt_text.1432: Nor ever defile the current of rivers flowing seaward, nor foun­ tains, but specially avoid it.
tgt_text.1434: Thus do, and avoid the evil rumour of mortals.
tgt_text.1435: For evil report is light to lift with all ease,1 but painful to bear, and difficult to set aside.
tgt_text.1436: And no rumour wholly dies away, which many peoples shall have spread abroad;
tgt_text.1437: in sooth she, too, is a kind of goddess.
tgt_text.1438: Mind well, too, and teach thy servants fittingly the days 2 appointed of Jove;
tgt_text.1439: to Mit, the 30th day of each month, the best both for inspecting work done, and distributing allotted sustenance, when the peoples observe it, in deciding the right.
tgt_text.1441: For these following days are from counselling Jove.4
tgt_text.1442: In the first place, the first, the fourth, and the seventh, is a holy day:
tgt_text.1443: for on this last, Latona gave-birth-to Apollo of-the-golden-sword:
tgt_text.1445: these are two days, I ween, of the month far advancing, for getting ready the works of mortal' , und the eleventh and twelfth, both in truth are good, the one for shearing sheep, the other for reap­ ing laughing corn:
tgt_text.1446: but the twelfth is far better than the eleventh, for on it, look you, the high-hovering spider1 spins his threads in the long summer day, when also the wise ant harvests his heap.
tgt_text.1447: On this day, too, a woman should set up her loom, and put forth her work.
tgt_text.1448: But on the thirteenth of the beginning of the month 2 avoid commencing your sowing :
tgt_text.1449: though to set plants it is best.
tgt_text.1450: The sixteenth, however,3 is very unprofitable to plants, but auspicious for the birth of men, though for a girl it is not propitious, either to be first born, or to be joined in wedlock.
tgt_text.1451: Nor, in truth, is the first sixth day4 suitable for the birth of girls, but a favourable day for cutting kids and flocks of sheep, and for enclosing a fold for sheep.
tgt_text.1452: Fortunate is the day on which a man is born:
tgt_text.1453: but it is fond5 both of uttering rail­ leries, and of falsehoods, and wily words, and stealthy fond discourses.

tgt_text.1459: But be cautious in your mind to avoid gnawing the heart with grief on the twenty- fourth and fourth of the month:

tgt_text.1461: 1Then on the fourth2 of the month lead home a bride, after having examined the omens, which are best in this matter.

tgt_text.1464: On the seventeenth4 watch well, and cast upon the well-rounded thrashing-floor Demeter's holy gift;
