tgt_text.2533: 4 but when it pleases the bad to be insolent, and they corrupt the commons, and give judgments in favour of the unjust,5 for the sake of private gains and power, expect that that city will not long be kept tranquil,6 even though now it is settled in much calm, when these gains shall have become dear to the igno­ ble men, coming along with public hurt.
tgt_text.2534: For from these is sedition, and civil bloodshed of men, and to a state such as this a monarch would never be pleasing.
tgt_text.2535: Cyrnus, this state is still a state indeed:
tgt_text.2536: 1 but its people truly are other, who aforetime knew nor rights nor laws, but were wont to wear-out goat-skins about their sides, and to inhabit this city, like stags, without the walls.
tgt_text.2538: And now, son of Polypas, they are noble:
tgt_text.2539: but they who were bettermost of yore, now are of-low-degree:
tgt_text.2540: who can endure to look on3 these things ?
tgt_text.2541: They deceive also one another, laughing one at the other, conscious of the sentiments neither of bad nor good.
tgt_text.2542: Son of Polypas, get none of these citizens as a friend, with thine whole heart,4 for the sake of any advantage:
tgt_text.2543: but seem indeed to be friend to all in tongue, yet associate with none of them in any serious matter at all.
tgt_text.2544: For you will learn the minds of wretched men, that in their deeds there is no reliance.
tgt_text.2546: But they have loved tricks, and deceits, and crafts in suchwise, as men no longer in-a-sound-condition.
tgt_text.2548: Never, Cyrnus, trustingly consult with a mean man, when you may wish to accomplish a serious matter:
tgt_text.2549: but go to a man-of-worth, and take advice, after you have made great efforts, and accomplished, Cyrnus, a long journey afoot.
tgt_text.2550: Not even to all friends communicate wholly 1 a matter:
tgt_text.2551: few, look you, of many have a trusty mind.
tgt_text.2552: Rely on but few men when you take in hand great deeds, lest ever, Cyrnus, you find incurable sorrow.
tgt_text.2553: A faithful man is worthy to-be-prized-equally with gold and silvery 0 Cyrnus, in vexatious doubt.
tgt_text.2554: Few men, son of Poly pas, will you find, as comrades, proving themselves faith­ ful in difficult circumstances, who would have the courage, possessing a like-minded spirit, to share alike good fortunes and bad.
tgt_text.2556: And of these you will not find, by seeking even among all men, such a number in all as one ship would not carry :
tgt_text.2557: 4 upon whose tongue as well as eyes a-sense-of-shame is set, nor does gain lead them to a base dealing.
tgt_text.2558: Do not caress me in words, and keep your mind and heart elsewhere, 1 if you love me and if there dwells in you a faith­ ful mind.
tgt_text.2559: Either love me, cherishing a sincere mind, or dis­ own and hate me, having raised a quarrel openly.
tgt_text.2561: But he who, with one tongue, has yet his mind at variance, this man, Cyrnus, is a formidable comrade, better as a too than when a friend.
tgt_text.2562: If a man shall praise you for so long as he sees you,3 but, when removed elsewhere, launches forth an evil tongue,4 such a comrade, look you, is not by any means a very good friend, who would say what is most acceptable with his tongue, but thinks differently.
tgt_text.2563: But be such an one my friend, who, knowing his comrade, even if he be troublesome in disposi­ tion,5 bears him as a brother.
tgt_text.2564: Do you, I pray, my friend, ponder these things in your mind, and at some time hereafter you will remember me.
tgt_text.2565: Let no man persuade thee, Cyrnus, to love a bad man.
tgt_text.2567: For what benefit is that man, if he be a friend ?
tgt_text.2568: Neither would he rescue you from severe trouble and loss, nor when he has what is good, would he be willing to share this.
tgt_text.2569: 'Tis the vainest thanks to one that does good to them- of-low-degree,1 all one with sowing the wide-waters of the gray brine.
tgt_text.2571: Since neither if you sow the waters-wide, would you reap a thick crop, nor benefiting the mean, would you be requited in turn with benefit.
tgt_text.2572: For the mean have an in­ satiate mind :
tgt_text.2573: if you shall have erred in one thing, spilt is the love arising from all the ancient kindnesses.
tgt_text.2575: But the noble in the highest degree receive and enjoy benefits, and retain memory of good deeds, and gratitude in aftertime.
tgt_text.2577: Never make the mean man friend and comrade,6 but ever fly from him as a bad harbour.
tgt_text.2578: Many, look you, are com­ panions in drinking and eating,6 but fewer in a serious mat­ ter.
tgt_text.2579: And nought is harder to discern than a friend of-base- olloy,7 0 Cyrnus, or of more value than caution.
tgt_text.2580: The loss of alloyed gold or silver is to-be-borne,1 and it is easy for a shrewd man to detect:
tgt_text.2581: but if the mind of a friend within his breast is untrue without-your-knowledge, and he has a treach­ erous heart within him, this is the falsest thing that God hath made for loan, this the most distressing of all to discern.
tgt_text.2582: For you cannot know man's mind nor woman's,2 before you have proved it, like as of a beast-of-burden.
tgt_text.2583: Nor could you guess it, as if at any time you had gone to a ware exposed for sale,3 for oftentimes appearances4 deceive the judgment.
tgt_text.2584: Pray, son-of-Polypas, to be foremost neither in dignity nor wealth :
tgt_text.2585: 5 but only let there be luck to a man.
tgt_text.2586: Nought among men is better than a father and mother, to whom holy justice is a care.
tgt_text.2588: No one, Cyrnus, is himself the cause of loss and gain :
tgt_text.2589: but of both these the gods are givers.
tgt_text.2590: Nor doth any man toil, knowing within his heart as touch- log the issue, whether 'tis well or ill.
tgt_text.2592: For oftentimes think­ ing that he will bring about evil, he is wont to bring about good, ay, and thinking to cause good, he causes ill.
tgt_text.2593: Neither to any man do as many things as he may wish arrive :
tgt_text.2594: for the bounds of stern impossibility hinder them.
tgt_text.2595: But we men entertain vain thoughts, knowing nothing.
tgt_text.2597: The gods accom­ plish all things after their own mind.
tgt_text.2598: None ever, son of Polypas, having deceived a guest or a suppliant among mortals, has escaped the eye of the im­ mortals.
tgt_text.2600: Choose also rather to live religiously with small means,4 than to be rich, having gotten riches unjustly.
tgt_text.2601: In justice is all virtue collectively, yea, and every man, Cyrnus, if just, is good.
tgt_text.2602: Wealth indeed fortune gives even to a man wholly bad,5 but excellence attends few men, 0 Cyrnus.
tgt_text.2603: Insolence,1 0 Cyrnus, the god is wont to present as the first evil to the man, whom he is about to hold in no esteem.
tgt_text.2604: Ful­ ness, look you, breeds insolence,2 whensoever wealth attends a mean man, and one whose mind is not sound.
tgt_text.2605: Do not ever, having become enraged at a man, 0 Cyrnus, throw-in-his-teeth3 heart-breaking poverty, or base want-of- means.
tgt_text.2606: For Jove, look you, inclines the scale now to one, and now to another, so that one while they should be rich, and at another time have nothing.
tgt_text.2608: Never speak in public, Cyrnus, big words;
tgt_text.2609: for no man knows what a night and day bring about for a man.
tgt_text.2611: Many, I wot, enjoy a mean mind, but a noble fortune :
tgt_text.2612: to whom that which seems ill turns out good.
tgt_text.2613: There are, too, who toil with both good counsel and ill luck, but accom­ plishment does not follow their works.
tgt_text.2614: 6No man is either wealthy or poor, mean or noble, without the help of the gods.
tgt_text.2616: One man has one ill, another another ;
tgt_text.2617: but in strict truth, no one of men whom the sun looks upon is blest.
tgt_text.2619: But whom the gods honour, even he who finds fault, commends, though there is no regard for a man,Pray to the gods, whose is great might ;
tgt_text.2620: nought happens to man without the gods, either good things or bad.
tgt_text.2622: Poverty most of all things breaks down a noble man,4 more even, 0 Cyrnus, than hoary age and hot-ague.
tgt_text.2623: And it in truth he ought to flee, and to cast it even into the deep, deep sea,5 and down steep rocks.
tgt_text.2624: For every man subdued by poverty can neither say nor do anything, but his tongue is bound.
tgt_text.2625: One ought then, Cyrnus, to seek alike over earth and the broad back of the sea for a riddance from hard poverty.
tgt_text.2627: To die, dear Cyrnus, is better for a poor man than to live worn down by hard poverty.
tgt_text.2629: We seek for well-bred rams, asses, and horses,8 Cyrnus, and every one wishes that those from a noble breed should cover.
tgt_text.2631: But a well-born man cares not to marry a mean woman, a mean man's daughter, if he give her much wealth.
tgt_text.2632: No woman refuses to be wife of a mean man if he be rich, but prefers that he be wealthy2 instead of noble.
tgt_text.2634: noble man weds mean man's daughter, and mean man the daughter of the noble.
tgt_text.2635: Wealth is wont to mix the breed.
tgt_text.2636: Then marvel not, son of Polypas, that the race of citizens is obscured,3 for noble is mixed with base.
tgt_text.2637: The man-of-rank weds the woman-without-fame, he him­ self, look you, leads her home, though he knows that she is base-born, because he is induced by her riches ;
tgt_text.2638: for stern necessity urges him on,4 which also makes a man's mind wretched.
tgt_text.2639: But to whatsoever man riches shall have come from Jove,5 and by just means, and with clean hands, they remain ever stedfastly.
tgt_text.2640: Though if a man unjustly shall acquire beyond what-is-proper with covetous spirit, or by an oath, having taken beyond what is just, at the moment he seems to bear off some gain, but in the end again there is ill, for the mind of the gods is wont to be superior.
tgt_text.2642: But these things deceive the mind of men ;
tgt_text.2643: for not at the very time of the acts do the immortals take vengeance on errors.;
tgt_text.2644: But one man in his own person is wont to pay a bitter debt, another attaches ruin hereafter to his own chil­ dren.
tgt_text.2646: And another justice does not catch ;
tgt_text.2647: for unscrupulous death was beforehand sitting on his eyelids,2 bringing fate.
tgt_text.2648: To an exile, believe me, none is a friend and faithful com­ rade,3 and this is more vexatious than banishment itself.
tgt_text.2649: Verily, to drink much wine is bad,4 but if a man drink it prudently, 'tis not bad but good.
tgt_text.2650: Cyrnus, direct a various habit towards all your friends,5 mingling with your own the temper which each has.
tgt_text.2651: Get thee the temper of the polypus,6 with-tangled-twisting-arms, which on any rock to which he has attached himself appears such as it is to look upon.
tgt_text.2652: Now follow this way, now be­ come different in complexion ;
tgt_text.2653: the wisdom of versatility is something of a rapid kind.
tgt_text.2655: Be not too indignant when citizens are in a state of disturbance, 0 Cyrnus ;
tgt_text.2656: but go on the middle path, as I do.
tgt_text.2657: Whoso, look you, thinks that his neighbour knows nothing, but that he himself alone possesses intricate counsels, he, I wot, is senseless, reft of sound mind:
tgt_text.2658: 1 for we all are Be- quainted equally with crafty counsels.
tgt_text.2659: But one chooses not to follow filthy lucre, whilst to another faithless wile-weav- ings are more agreeable.
tgt_text.2660: 2Now no limit of wealth has been made-clear to men,3 for they who of us now have most substance, strive after twice as much.
tgt_text.2662: Riches verily to mortals become folly.
tgt_text.2664: And from it up-starts ruin, which when Jove shall send upon them worn-and-weary, one at one time and another at another possesses.
tgt_text.2665: Though he be citadel and tower to an empty-minded populace,5 Cyrnus, the noble man gets little share of praise.
tgt_text.2666: Nor longer, I wot, becomes it us, as men in a state of safety, to destroy, as it were, the walls of a city about to be taken.
tgt_text.2668: To thee indeed I have given wings, wherewith thou wilt fly1 over boundless deep, and all earth, easily borne-aloft;
tgt_text.2669: and thou wilt be present at all banquets and feasts, resting in the mouths of many;
tgt_text.2670: 2 thee too with sweet-voiced pipes young men gracefully lovely shall sing well and tunefully ;
tgt_text.2671: and whensoe'er thou comest to the much-lamenting homes of Hades, beneath earth's murky vaults, never more, even though dead, shalt thou lose thy renown, nor,3 I ween, escape notice, having ever imperishable fame among men, 0 Cyrnus, whilst thou tarriest in the land of Greece, or up and down the isles, crossing over the fishy barren deep, and not seated on the backs of horses ;
tgt_text.2672: but the tasteful gifts of violet-wreathed5 Muses will convey thee, for with all, to whom, even among posterity, minstrelsy is a care, thou wilt be likewise, as long as there shall be earth and sun.
tgt_text.2673: I, however, meet with small reverence from thee, but with words thou deceivest me, as a little child.
tgt_text.2675: That which is most just is most noble ;
tgt_text.2677: but the gaining the object of one's love is the most pleasant thing.
tgt_text.2678: 2I am as it were a well-bred racing mare,3 but I carry a very mean man :
tgt_text.2679: and this to me is most vexatious.
tgt_text.2680: Often ere now have I been ready to burst the bridle and flee, hav­ ing thrust from me my mean charioteer.
tgt_text.2681: Wine is not drunk by me,4 since with a tender maiden, an­ other man, far meaner than I, has the upper hand.
tgt_text.2682: Cold water to my sorrow her dear parents drink with her, so that she at the same time fetches water and bears me groaningly.
tgt_text.2683: Then having clasped the damsel round, I kissed her neck, and she spoke tenderly with her lips.
tgt_text.2684: Known, look you, is poverty, even though it be strange, for it neither comes to the market nor the law-suits.
tgt_text.2685: For everywhere it has the lesser share, and everywhere 'tis mock­ ed :
tgt_text.2686: 1 everywhere also, wheresoever it may be, it is equally hostile.
tgt_text.2687: Equally, in truth, to mortal men the gods have given the other things,2 to wit, wretched old age and youth.
tgt_text.2688: But 'tis the worst of all the evils among men, and more unlucky than death and all diseases, after that you have reared children, and afforded them all things suitable, and laid up money for them, having experienced much trouble, if they hate their father,3 and pray that he may perish, and abhor him as if he were a beggar coming to them.
tgt_text.2689: It is likely that a mean man would ill respect the rules of justice, since he stands-in-awe-of no divine-vengeance here­ after.
tgt_text.2691: For a worthless mortal may take up many impracti­ cable things at the moment, and deem that he arranges all well.
tgt_text.2692: Relying on none of the citizens, advance one step,5 trusting neither oath nor covenant, not even if a man, wishing to give pledges, chooses 1 to give Jove, the supreme king of im­ mortals, as his surety.
tgt_text.2693: For verily in a city so malignantly- blaming as this, nothing pleases, and according as any one does, so they are called far the more senseless.
tgt_text.2695: But now the ills of the well-born are good things to the mean of men, and be­ come a law to the devious.
tgt_text.2697: impudence and insolence, having mastered justice, possess the whole earth.
tgt_text.2698: Neither does a lion always feast on flesh :
tgt_text.2699: but him, strong though he be, yet nevertheless perplexity seizes.
tgt_text.2701: To a babbling man silence is the hardest burden, but an unlearned man, if he speak, is so to all in whose presence he may be.
tgt_text.2703: yet the mixing up of such a man in a banquet is necessary.
tgt_text.2704: Nor does he wish to be a friend, when ill has chanced to a man,4 even though he may have been born of one and the same womb.
tgt_text.2705: Be bitter and sweet, harsh and kind,5 to hired servants and slaves and neighbours near- your-doors.
tgt_text.2706: It is not meet often-to-change6 a good life, but to keep peace:
tgt_text.2707: and to alter the ill life, until you have brought it right.
tgt_text.2708: The mean are not wholly mean from the womb, but through having cemented a friendship with mean men.
tgt_text.2710: And they have learned worthless works, and slanderous words, and in­ solence, supposing that all was true which those men said.
tgt_text.2711: Among companions-at-a-meal,2 be a prudent man ;
tgt_text.2712: and deem that all escapes his notice, as if absent.
tgt_text.2713: Know how to endure jokes, and be brave out-of-doors, understanding what temper each has.
tgt_text.2714: Among the mad indeed I am exceeding mad ;
tgt_text.2715: 3 but among the just I am of all men most just.
tgt_text.2716: Many mean men are rich, look you ;
tgt_text.2717: and noble men are poor, yet with these we will not exchange their wealth for our excellence:
tgt_text.2719: 4 for the latter is ever secure, but riches now one and now another of men possesses.
tgt_text.2720: Cyrnus, a noble man bath a judgment always firm, and is bold when set amidst blessings and amidst ills.
tgt_text.2721: But if the god shall present to a mean man substance and wealth, in-his- folly be is unable to contain his meanness.
tgt_text.2723: Do not ever on a slight pretext ruin a man7 that is a friend, trusting, Cyrnus, to a harsh slander.
tgt_text.2724: If a man in every instance should be wrath at the faults of his friends, never would men be in-concord or in-friendship one with the other.
tgt_text.2725: For faults follow-after mortal men,1 Cyrnus :
tgt_text.2726: but the gods choose not to endure them.
tgt_text.2727: Even the slow man with-good-counsel hath caught the swift man in the pursuit, Cyrnus, with the aid of the straight­ forward justice of the immortal gods.
tgt_text.2729: Quietly, as I do, pursue the middle way with thy feet,3 nor give to one party the property of the other, 0 Cyrnus.
tgt_text.2730: Never, Cyrnus, kindly-treat an exile on the ground of hope,4 for not even, if he has returned home, does he become any more the same.
tgt_text.2731: Make-too-much haste in nothing, the mean is best of all:
tgt_text.2732: 5 and thus, Cyrnus, thou shalt have excellence, which too it is hard to get.
tgt_text.2734: Jove grant me both requital of my friends, who love me,6 and that I may be more powerful than my foes.
tgt_text.2735: And so should I have the character of being a god among men, if the fate of death should overtake me, when I had recompensed them.
tgt_text.2736: But, 0 Jove, accomplish me, thou Olympian god, a seasonable prayer, grant me to experience in return for ills some good also.
tgt_text.2737: But oh might I die, 1 unless I find some cessation from evil cares, and if thou givest but sorrows in return for sorrows.
tgt_text.2739: and there does not appear to me a means of vengeance on the men who perforce have plundered and possess my property;
tgt_text.2740: but like a dog2 I have crossed a mountain-torrent, having shaken off every­ thing in the rain-swollen stream.
tgt_text.2741: Whose black blood may it be mine to drink :
tgt_text.2742: 3 and oh might the good Genius aid me, who would accomplish these things to my mind.
tgt_text.2743: O worthless poverty, why tarriest thou, failing to go 4 to an­ other man ?
tgt_text.2744: and why, prithee, dost love me, not desiring it ?
tgt_text.2745: Nay, go, and visit another house, nor along with us be ever sharing this wretched life.
tgt_text.2746: Be of good courage, Cyrnus, in ills, for amid blessings too thou wast wont to rejoice,5 when the lot fell to thee to have a share of these too.
tgt_text.2747: And even as thou hast received ill out of blessings, even so also, praying to the gods, try to emerge again.
tgt_text.2749: 1 for when exhibit­ ing any ill, 0 Cyrnus, you have but few carers for your ca­ lamity.
tgt_text.2750: The heart of a man, look you, 0 Cyrnus, having suffered great loss, is weakened ;
tgt_text.2751: 2 but when he takes vengeance, after­ wards it is increased.
tgt_text.2752: Beguile your enemy with good words:
tgt_text.2753: 3 but when he shall have come into your power, take vengeance on him, having admitted of no excuse.
tgt_text.2754: Restrain thy mind,4 and let mildness ever attend thy tongue :
tgt_text.2755: the heart, look you, of mean men is more sharp than is meet.
tgt_text.2756: I cannot understand the mind of the citizens, 5 which they entertain :
tgt_text.2757: for neither if I do them good, nor ill, do I please them:
tgt_text.2758: and many blame me, alike the base-born and the well- born :
tgt_text.2759: but none of the unwise can imitate me.
tgt_text.2760: Do not, goading me perforce,6 and against my will, drive me under the waggon's yoke, drawing me, Cyrnus, too much into friendship.
tgt_text.2761: Kind Jove, I marvel at thee, for thou rulest over all,1 having honour thyself and vast power.
tgt_text.2762: Well knowest thou the mind of men, and the spirit of each ;
tgt_text.2763: and thy might, 0 king, is highest of all.
tgt_text.2764: How is it then, 0 son of Saturn, that thy purpose has-the-heart to hold men that are sinners, and the just man, in the same portion,2 both if thy mind shall have been turned towards moderation, and if towards the inso­ lence of men yielding to unjust deeds ?
tgt_text.2765: Neither is anything defined by the deity for mortals, nor the way in which walk­ ing a man may please the immortals.
tgt_text.2766: But nevertheless they hold wealth harmless ;
tgt_text.2767: while they who keep their mind aloof from worthless deeds, still are-wont-to-find the mother of poverty, want-of-means,4 though they love what is just;
tgt_text.2768: want-of-means, which leads on the spirit of men to error, hurting their minds within their bosoms by strong necessity.
tgt_text.2769: So a man has-the-courage, though he wishes it not, to bear many disgraces,5 yielding to want, which truly teaches many lessons, to wit, falsehoods, deceits, and mischievous strifes, to a man even against his will :
tgt_text.2770: 6 and they seem to him no evil, for it also breeds vexatious lack-of-means.
tgt_text.2771: But in poverty both the mean man, and he who is far better-born are seen,1 whensoever, I mean, want takes-hold-on-them.
tgt_text.2772: For the spirit of the former indulges in unjust thoughts, no, nor even is a right sentiment ever inherent in his breast:
tgt_text.2773: but the mind of the latter on-the -contrary follows neither bad nor goodfortunes:
tgt_text.2774: it is right however that the bettermost man should have the courage to meet both the one and the other.
tgt_text.2776: Respect your friends,3 and flee oaths that-ruin-men:
tgt_text.2777: but avoid, and give-heed-to, the wrath of immortals.
tgt_text.2778: Make too much haste in nothing :
tgt_text.2779: in all the works of man the-fitting-season 4 is best:
tgt_text.2780: often a man, seeking gain, is hastening towards rank-and-honours, whom fortune readily draws astray into a great sin, and is wont to make him deem without difficulty that what is really evil, that is good;
tgt_text.2781: but that what is good-and-useful, that is bad.
tgt_text.2783: Most dear though thou art, thou hast erred ;
tgt_text.2784: and I, look you, am nowise to blame, but thou thyself hast chanced on sentiments not good.
tgt_text.2785: No treasure wilt thou lay up for thy children better than a sense-of-shame, which also, Cyrnus, attends good men.
tgt_text.2786: Of no man, whom judgment and whom power attends,6 0 Cyrnus, seem thou to be a worse companion.
tgt_text.2787: But when I drink, I am not about to become so drunk,.
tgt_text.2788: nor does wine lead me on, so far as to speak a harsh word respect­ ing you.
tgt_text.2789: None like me can I find, when I seek a trusty associate,2 in whom there is no guile.
tgt_text.2790: But when I have come to the touch-stone I am rubbed beside baser metal, as gold beside lead, and a mind of superiority 3 is in me.
tgt_text.2791: Many things pass me by, even though I am conscious of them:
tgt_text.2792: but of necessity I am silent,4 knowing our power.
tgt_text.2793: To many men well-fitting doors are not set on their tongue,5 and many things are a care to them, which should be uncared for.
tgt_text.2794: For oft that which is bad is better, if stored-up within, and good, having come abroad, is better than what is bad.
tgt_text.2796: Of all things indeed to men on-the earth, not to be born,7 and not to see the rays of the piercing sun, is best:
tgt_text.2797: but that when born he should, as soon as possible, cross the gates of Hades, and lie low, having heaped together for himself much earthyTo beget and nurture a child is easier than to implant right feelings :
tgt_text.2798: 2 this at all events no one has yet contrived, in mak­ ing the senseless sensible, and the mean noble ;
tgt_text.2799: but if a god had granted this, I wot, to the sons of Æsculapius,3 to cure meanness, and the infatuated minds of men, many and great wages would they earn.
tgt_text.2800: And if mind were capable-of-being created and implanted in man, 4 never would worthless son have been born of worthy father, but he would have been heedful of prudent discourses.
tgt_text.2802: But by teaching you will never make the mean man noble.
tgt_text.2803: He is a fool, who has my mind indeed in safe-keeping, but pays no attention6 to his own proper mind.
tgt_text.2804: No one, look you, is in all things blest, but the nobler man has the heart 1to endure what is evil, and still is not known- to-all.
tgt_text.2805: But the baser man neither in woe nor weal knows how to remain in possession of spirit:
tgt_text.2806: the gifts of the gods come variously to mortals;
tgt_text.2807: yet it is right to have the courage to hold the gifts of the immortals,2 such as they give.
tgt_text.2808: If you choose to drench me, undefiled water shall flow ever clear from the top of my head:
tgt_text.2809: and you shall find me in all deeds like-as refined gold,2 ruddy to look-on, when rubbed by touch-stone;
tgt_text.2810: the colour of which from above the dark rust doth not touch, nor mould, but it has its brilliancy4 always pure.0 man, hadst thou obtained a share of j udgment, even as thou hast of folly, and hadst thou been sensible as thou art senseless, to many of these citizens thou wouldst appear an- object-of-envy, just as now thou art nothing-worth.
tgt_text.2811: 5A young woman, look you, is not an expedient thing for an old man :
tgt_text.2812: 6 for she, like a light boat, does not heed the rudder, nor do anchors hold her:
tgt_text.2813: but, having burst her fasten­ ings, oft in the nights she hath another harbour.
tgt_text.2814: Never set thy mind at least on things impracticable,1 nor long for wealth, of which there is no accomplishment.
tgt_text.2815: Easily, look you, the gods have given wealth, neither any- thing mean, nor noble:
tgt_text.2816: but there is glory attendant on a dif­ ficult work.
tgt_text.2818: and let what is just be dear to you, nor let gain, when it is base, get the upper hand of you.
tgt_text.2820: Force no one of these against his will to remain with us, 4 nor bid any, if he wishes it not, go out of doors.
tgt_text.2821: Nor rouse in-his-sleep, Simonides, whomsoever of us, drunken with wine, soft sleep shall have seized.
tgt_text.2823: Neither bid him that is watchful, sleep against his will, for every-thing-done-by- compulsion is vexatious.
tgt_text.2825: And to him that chooses to drink let one stand near and pour-out-wine:
tgt_text.2826: not every night does it happen to us to live delicately.
tgt_text.2827: Now I, for I have due measure7 of sweet wine, will go home, and be mindful of care-relaxing sleep;
tgt_text.2828: and I will show that wine is most pleas­ ant for a man to drink, for neither am I a whit sober, nor yet am I very drunk.
tgt_text.2829: Now whoso exceeds the due measure of drinking, that man is no longer master of his tongue or mind:
tgt_text.2830: but he speaks scandalous words,2 which, to the sober, seem disgraceful, and nothing is he ashamed to do, whenso­ ever he may be drunk.
tgt_text.2831: Though be were sensible before, then he is a fool:
tgt_text.2832: do you, then, knowing these things, not drink wine in excess;
tgt_text.2833: but either, before you are intoxicated, rise and go, 3 lest your stomach constrain you, like a worthless hireling for-the-day;
tgt_text.2834: or be present, and do not drink:
tgt_text.2835: but you, though knowing these things, are ever babbling this fool­ ish word, " pour-in :
tgt_text.2836: " therefore, look you, you are drunk.
tgt_text.2837: For one cup is taken " to friendship;
tgt_text.2839: 4 this you offer as a libation to the gods:
tgt_text.2840: the fourth you hold in your hand.
tgt_text.2841: And you know not how to say nay ;
tgt_text.2842: 5 now, look you, that man will be invincible, who, though he drink many cups, shall say nothing silly.
tgt_text.2843: But do ye discourse well, tarry­ ing beside the bowl, long keeping-off contentions one from the other;
tgt_text.2844: speaking fairly and evenly alike to one and with all, and thus a banquet becomes not unpleasant.
tgt_text.2845: Wine belongs to the senseless man as well as the sensible.
tgt_text.2846: When, however, it is drunk above measure, it is wont to render the mind light.
tgt_text.2848: In fire, indeed, skilful men try gold and silvery but wine is wont to show the mind of a man, even though he be ex­ ceeding sensible;
tgt_text.2849: wine which when drinking he is wont to praise beyond measure, so as to disgrace one being even wise aforetime.
tgt_text.2850: My head, Onomacritus, is heavy-with-wine,3 and wine does violence to me, but I am no longer master of my senses;
tgt_text.2852: Come, let me rise and try whe­ ther perchance the wine bath my feet too,4 and my mind with­ in my breast.
tgt_text.2853: I fear lest, in my drunkenness, I should do anything foolish, and incur a great disgrace.
tgt_text.2855: 5 but if a man drink it with- judgment, 'tis not bad but good.
tgt_text.2856: So thou hast come, Clearistus, after having accomplished a passage across the deep sea,6 hither, wretched man, a beggar to a beggar.
tgt_text.2857: Under the ship's sides, truly, we will place benches, Clearistus,1 such as we have, and as the gods give us:
tgt_text.2858: and we will supply the best of what we have:
tgt_text.2859: but should any one come, being a friend of thine, say to him, " Sit-at- meat, an' thou lovest me."
tgt_text.2860: I will neither set apart aught of my substance, nor, for the sake of entertaining thee, will we bring aught more from other quarters.
tgt_text.2861: Then should any inquire my means of subsistence,2 thus tell him, that I live with diffi­ culty as regards living well, but very well for one living with difficulty:
tgt_text.2862: so as not to fail even one guest of my father's, though I am not able to afford feasts to more men.
tgt_text.2863: Not to no purpose, Plutus, do mortals honour thee most, for of-a-truth thou bearest distress with ease.
tgt_text.2865: For verily it is fitting for the bettermost to have wealth indeed, but pover­ ty is proper for a mean man to bear.
tgt_text.2866: Alas me for youth and wretched old age, the latter coming on, and the former departing.
tgt_text.2867: I have betrayed neither any friend nor trusty comrade, nor is there aught servile in my spirit.
tgt_text.2868: Ever is my heart cheered,4 whensoever I shall have heard the delightsome sound of vocal flutes.
tgt_text.2869: And I rejoice in drink­ ing well, and in listing to a flute-player;
tgt_text.2870: I delight, too, in carrying the gay lyre in my hands.
tgt_text.2871: Never is a slave's head erect, but always crooked, and has the neck askance.
tgt_text.2873: For neither from the squill do roses or hyacinths spring, no, nor ever from a bond-woman a free- spirited childNo man, dear Cyrnus, forges fetters for himself unless the gods beguile my judgment.
tgt_text.2874: I fear, 0 son of Polypas, lest insolence, even the insolence which destroyed the savage Centaurs, should ruin this stated'
tgt_text.2875: Tis right that I, 0 Cyrnus, should adjudicate this cause by rule and square,3 and deal fair play to both sides, namely, to oracular birds, and to burnt sacrifices, that so I may not in­ cur the foul disgrace of error.
tgt_text.2876: Never do violence to any one through wickedness :
tgt_text.2877: for to the just man nought is better than good-conduct.
tgt_text.2878: 4A voiceless messenger stirs up, 0 Cyrnus, war-of-many tears, 5 seen clearly as it is from a conspicuous mountain-peak.
tgt_text.2879: Nay,then, place bridles on your swift-footed steeds, for methinks that they will encounter hostile men :
tgt_text.2880: nor long the way which they will traverse between us and the foe, unless the gods de­ ceive my judgment.
tgt_text.2881: It behoves a man lying in severe griefs to take heart, 1 and to ask deliverance from them at the hands of the immortal gods.
tgt_text.2883: the danger, look you, stands on a razor's edge:
tgt_text.2884: 2 at one moment you shall have much:
tgt_text.2886: so that you neither become exceeding rich in possessions, no, nor thrust yourself into much want-of-means.
tgt_text.2887: Be it mine to have somewhat myself but to bestow the most of the riches of foes on my friends to enjoy.
tgt_text.2888: Now 'tis meet that one should be invited to a banquet, and sit beside a worthy man, versed in all wisdom, so as to un­ derstand him 4 whensoever he shall utter aught-of-wisdom, that so you may be instructed, and go home to your house with this gain.
tgt_text.2889: Delighting myself in youth I sport-and-sing:
tgt_text.2890: 5 for, when I have lost my life, I shall lie long beneath the earth, like a voiceless stone;
tgt_text.2891: and shall quit the delightful light of the sun, and, though I be a man-of-worth, yet shall see nothing any more.
tgt_text.2892: Opinion, indeed, is a great evil to men,6 but experience a very excellent thing:
tgt_text.2893: many of the bettermost men have an opinion unproved-by-experience.
tgt_text.2894: Do good, and good shall be done by you :
tgt_text.2895: 1 but wherefore send you another messenger ?
tgt_text.2896: the tidings of a benefit is easy.
tgt_text.2897: My friends abandon me, yes, because I avoid my enemy, as pilot avoids the low-rocks2 in-the-sea.
tgt_text.2899: Tis easier to make a mean man out of a bettermost man, 3 than a noble man of a base:
tgt_text.2901: I am not of an age to learn.
tgt_text.2903: and I veil myself when I approach him,4 having the volatile spirit of a little bird.
tgt_text.2904: I hate also a roaming woman,5 and a wanton man, who desires to plough the furrow of another.
tgt_text.2905: But the things which have gone by, it is impossible should become undone:
tgt_text.2906: 6 the future, however, be that a care to our caution.
tgt_text.2907: Danger, I wot, is attendant on all works, neither knoweth any one,7 when a matter begins, where he is likely to land.
tgt_text.2908: But the man who endeavours to be popular, without fore­ thought, 8 is wont to fall into great and severe ruin.
tgt_text.2909: Him how- ever who doeth well it is the deity that invests with every­ thing, with lucky chances, and riddance from folly.
tgt_text.2910: It is right to endure what the gods give to men, and to bear easily the lot of both classes.
tgt_text.2911: Neither when distressed with ills be vexed at heart, nor be delighted on a sudden with good fortune, before you have seen the extreme end.
tgt_text.2912: 1Good Sir, let us be companions one to another at a dis­ tance.
tgt_text.2914: There is satiety of everything save wealth.
tgt_text.2915: Long then let us be even friends;
tgt_text.2916: but do thou associate with other men also, who better know thy mind.
tgt_text.2917: You have not escaped-my-notice as you walked along the road, on which even aforetime you used to driver stealing my friendship.
tgt_text.2918: Away with you, hateful to gods, and faithless to men, you who had in your bosom a chilly spotted snake.
tgt_text.2919: Such-like deeds, such insolence, ruined the Magnesians also,4 as now possesses this sacred city.
tgt_text.2920: Fulness hath ere now destroyed far more men,5 look you, than famine, to wit, as many as were desirous of having more than their share.
tgt_text.2921: At the beginning a lie gets small thanks,6 but at last base lucre, in truth, and ill arise, both of them :
tgt_text.2922: nor is there any- thing noble to any man, whom a lie attends, even though it be the first that has gone forth from his mouth.
tgt_text.2923: It is not hard to blame one's neighbour, no, nor to praise him:
tgt_text.2924: these things are a care to mean men.
tgt_text.2925: And mean men do not choose to be silent, prating mischief1 rather, but the noble know how to preserve moderation in all things.
tgt_text.2926: No one of the present race of men doth the sun look down upon, being entirely good and moderate.
tgt_text.2927: Not to any great extent are all things accomplished to men'a liking, for immortals2 are far-superior to mortals.
tgt_text.2928: I am much tost-about in difficulties, being vexed at heart:
tgt_text.2929: for we have not outrun extreme poverty.
tgt_text.2930: Every one honours a -rich man, but dishonours a poor:
tgt_text.2931: 3 and in all men there is the same mind.
tgt_text.2932: All-kinds-of-baseness exist among men, and all-kinds-of excellence, and devices for livelihood.
tgt_text.2934: Tis hard for a sensible man to speak much among the senseless, and so it is always to be silent:
tgt_text.2936: In truth, 'tis disgraceful for a drunken man to be amongst sober men :
tgt_text.2937: 4 and disgraceful if a sober man remains among the drunken.
tgt_text.2938: Man's-estate and youth lighten a man's mind,1 and stir up the spirits of many to error.
tgt_text.2939: Whoso hath not a mind that is master of his inclinations, lie, I wot, Cyrnus, lies ever in follies, and in great errors.
tgt_text.2940: Consult twice and thrice on whatever shall have come into your mind,2 for a hasty man, look you, is hurried-to- ruin.
tgt_text.2941: Judgment and sense-of-shame attend men that are good, who now are really few among the many.
tgt_text.2942: Hope and hazard are alike among men:
tgt_text.2944: 3 for both these are severe deities.
tgt_text.2945: Often beyond both expectation and hope 4 it is given men to discover the works of men, but success is not wont to fol low their counsels.
tgt_text.2946: A single individual, look you, troubles neither one-well- affected, nor his foe,5 unless he meet with a serious matter.
tgt_text.2947: Many are friends and comrades over the bowl,6 but fewer in a serious matter.
tgt_text.2948: Few companions would you find faithful protectors, when you are placed in great perplexity of spirit.
tgt_text.2949: Now at length a sense-of-shame hath perished among man­ kind,1 but shamelessness roams over the earth.
tgt_text.2950: Thou luckless poverty, why, seated on my shoulders,2 dost thou disgrace my body and mind ?
tgt_text.2951: Nay, thou teachest me against my will perforce many disgraceful arts, though I know from men good and noble lessons.
tgt_text.2952: May I be fortunate, and dear to the immortal gods,3 0 Cyrnus ;
tgt_text.2953: then am I eager for no other excellence.
tgt_text.2954: Along with thee, Cyrnus, when thou hast suffered misfor­ tune, we are all distrest:
tgt_text.2955: but of-a-truth grief for another lasts but-for-a-day.
tgt_text.2956: In hard fortunes be not at all excessively disgusted at heart, neither rejoice in prosperity:
tgt_text.2957: for 'tis a noble man's course to bear all things.
tgt_text.2958: Nor is it right to swear this, “that this thing shall never be,"4 for the gods also, in whose hands is the issue, are wroth.
tgt_text.2959: Yet still one ought to do somewhat :
tgt_text.2960: 5 both good hath arisen from ill, and ill from good;
tgt_text.2961: ay, and the poor man very quickly becomes rich, while he who has possessed very much on a sudden is wont to lose everything, in fact, in a single night.
tgt_text.2962: And sensible man errs, and glory oft attends a sense.
tgt_text.2964: honour too even a mean man is wont to obtain.
tgt_text.2965: If I had wealth, Simonides, even such as I was acquainted with,1 I should not be vexed at associating with the noble.
tgt_text.2966: But now they (riches) pass-me-by, though I knew them,2 and I am mute through poverty, though still knowing better than many.
tgt_text.2967: Wherefore we are borne-on now, having pulled down our white sails,3 from the Melian Sea, through murky gloom :
tgt_text.2968: but they do not choose to bale the ship, and the sea sur­ mounts both the vessel's sides, whereby with great difficulty any one saves himself:
tgt_text.2969: yet the sailors are slumbering,4 and have made the pilot, good though he was, cease from his work, the pilot who used to watch over it understandingly.
tgt_text.2970: By force they plunder property, order is upset, and no longer is there an equal distribution in common :
tgt_text.2971: but the porters bear-rule, and the mean are above the noble.
tgt_text.2972: I fear lest haply the waves should ingulf the ship.
tgt_text.2974: Let thus much have been wrapt in riddles darkly,1 for the men-of-worth ;
tgt_text.2975: but a man, if he be wise, would be cognizant also of the evil.
tgt_text.2976: Many dunces have riches, but others seek what is noble,2 though harassed by severe poverty:
tgt_text.2978: the one class want-of-riches im­ pedes, of-intellect the other.
tgt_text.2981: Tis impossible for mortals to strive against immortals,4 or to deal out justice.
tgt_text.2983: It is not right to cherish5 what should not be cherished, nor to do what it were better to leave unaccomplished.
tgt_text.2984: With satisfaction mayest thou duly perform thy voyage through the great sea,6 and may Neptune bring thee home, a joy to thy friends.
tgt_text.2985: Many men, look you, being senseless, has fulness ruined, for 'tis hard to understand moderation, when good things are present.
tgt_text.2986: In truth, 0 my spirit, I cannot afford thee all things fit­ ting.
tgt_text.2989: for not by any means thou alone art fond of what is beautiful.
tgt_text.2990: When I am flourishing,1 friends are many ;
tgt_text.2991: but should any calamity have chanced upon me, few retain a faithful spirit.
tgt_text.2992: For to the multitude of men there is this virtue only, namely, to be rich :
tgt_text.2993: but of the rest, I wot, there is no use.
tgt_text.2995: Not even though you should have the sense of Rhadaman­ thus himself and be more knowing than Sisyphus, son of Æolus;
tgt_text.2996: (even he who by his cunning came-up-again from Hades, after having persuaded Proserpine by wily words, Proserpine, who gives oblivion to mortals, and misleads their mind:
tgt_text.2997: 4 and never hath any other devised this, I ween, whom­ soever in truth the black mist of death has enshrouded, and he has come to the chilly place of the dead, and crossed the dark portals 5 which confine the souls of the dead, even though they refuse:
tgt_text.2998: yet, verily, even thence came back the hero Sisy­ phus to the light of the sun through his own exceeding- shrewdness ;
tgt_text.2999: ) nor if you could make falsehoods like to truths,6 having the skilful tongue of the god-like Nestor, and were t swifter of foot than the fleet Harpies, and the sons of Boreas, whose feet go swiftly.
tgt_text.3000: Nay, then, 'tis right that all should lay up this maxim, that wealth has the most power among all.
tgt_text.3001: Equally rich, look you, are he to whom there is much silver and gold, and plains of wheat-producing earth, horses and mules;
tgt_text.3002: and he to whom that which is needful is ready, so that he may enjoy himself in pleasures of stomach, sides, and feet;
tgt_text.3004: for when the fitting season of these shall have arrived, and at-the-same-time their youthful prime is suitable, these are wealth to mortals:
tgt_text.3005: for no one goes to Hades with all his immense wealth.
tgt_text.3007: Neither by paying ransom can he escape death, or heavy diseases, or wretched old age coming upon him.
tgt_text.3008: O Father Jove, would that it might please the gods, that their insolence should delight sinners;
tgt_text.3009: 3 and that this might be agreeable to their mind, namely, that whoso ruthlessly works daring deeds in his heart, nowise standing-in-awe-of the gods, that he, I say, thereafter should atone for his evil deeds;
tgt_text.3010: and that the father's infatuation should not in after- time be a woe to the children.
tgt_text.3011: But that children, who, being born of an unjust sire, know and do justice, reverencing thy wrath, 0 son of Cronus, and from the very first loving the right amongst the citizens, should not pay the penalty for any transgression of their sires.
tgt_text.3012: May these things be agreeable to the blessed gods:
tgt_text.3013: but now he that commits wicked deeds escapes, and another presently suffers the punishment.
tgt_text.3014: Then how, 0 king of immortals, is it just, that whoso is aloof from unrighteous deeds, holding no transgression, nor sinful oath, but being righteous, should suffer what is not just ?
tgt_text.3015: What other mortal, too, I pray, when he looks at this man, would afterwards stand-in-awe-of the gods, and entertaining what feeling ?
tgt_text.3016: When an unrighteous, infatuated man,1 having avoid­ ed the wrath neither of any man nor of the immortals in any­ wise, doeth wrongs, and is glutted with wealth ;
tgt_text.3017: whereas the righteous are wasted, being worn out by severe poverty.
tgt_text.3018: Having learned this, dear comrade, get riches justly, keep­ ing a prudent spirit, afar from blind-folly, and ever remem­ bering these my words ;
tgt_text.3019: 2 then at the last you will commend me, giving heed to a wise speech.
tgt_text.3020: May Jove, dwelling in heaven, hold on high3 his right hand ever over this city for its health and safety, as well as the other immortal blessed gods;
tgt_text.3021: but may Apollo nerve my tongue and mind:
tgt_text.3022: and on the other hand let the holy melody sound with lyre,4 and also flute ;
tgt_text.3023: but let us, having made full drink-offerings to the gods, drink and speak pleasantly one with the other, in no wise fearing the war of the Medes.
tgt_text.3025: and, better still, be it ours,1 enjoying a cheerful spirit, aloof from cares to pass our days cheerily, and delight our­ selves, and to drive far away2 ill fates, wretched age, and the end of death.
tgt_text.3026: 'Tis meet that the Muses' servant and messenger,3 if he know aught special of wisdom, should not begrudge it:
tgt_text.3027: but should seek after some things, point out some, and invent others ;
tgt_text.3028: alone knowing for what purpose he should use them.
tgt_text.3029: O sovereign Phœbus, thou thyself fencedst the citadel4 in favour to Alcathous, son of Pelops;
tgt_text.3030: do thou then ward off from this city the insolent army of Medes,5 that so thy peo­ ple, in cheerfulness, as spring comes on, may send thee splen­ did hecatombs, delighting themselves with lyre, and lovely festival, with choirs of paeans, and shoutings around thine altar.
tgt_text.3031: For of a truth I fear, when I look on the folly and people-destroying seditions6 of the Greeks.
tgt_text.3032: Yet do thou, Phœbus, propitiously guard this our city.
tgt_text.3033: For I have gone aforetime both to the Sicilian land, and I have gone to Eu boea's vine-clad plain,1 and to Sparta, splendid city of reed- nursing Eurotas, and all did with alacrity entreat-me-kindly when I came.
tgt_text.3034: But no pleasure in them came over my spirit;
tgt_text.3035: so much, I wot, is nought else dearer than our father-land.
tgt_text.3037: Never may other fresher care present itself to me, in place of charming wisdom;
tgt_text.3038: 3 but may I ever, possessing this, de­ light myself with lyre, with dance, and song;
tgt_text.3039: and with these blessings may I have a noble mind.
tgt_text.3040: Harming by baneful deeds neither any stranger nor any of your townsmen, but, being just, delight your own mind:
tgt_text.3041: and of the unfeeling citizens some will speak ill of you, others better.
tgt_text.3042: The noble one man blames much:
tgt_text.3044: 4 but of the mean there is no record:
tgt_text.3045: but of men unblamed is none upon the earth;
tgt_text.3046: and 'tis best for him, of whom there is no care to the greater number.
tgt_text.3047: No one of men will either be, or hath been, born, who will go down to Hades pleasing to all.
tgt_text.3048: For not even he who reigns over mortals and immortals, Jove, son of Cronus, can please all mortals.
tgt_text.3049: It behoves, indeed, a man that goeth-to-consult-the oracle, Cyrnus,1 to keep more straightly than compasses, line, or rule ;
tgt_text.3050: such a man, I mean, as he to whom the god at Pytho, having given answer to the priestess, shall have indicated a prophecy from his rich sanctuary;
tgt_text.3051: for neither though you add aught would you discover any remedy, nor if you have diminished aught, would you escape the punishment of offence, on the part of the gods.
tgt_text.3052: I have experienced a thing nowise inferior to an unseemly death, but of all other things most vexatious, 0 Cyrnus.
tgt_text.3053: My friends have cast me off:
tgt_text.3054: so I, having drawn near to mine enemies, am about to see also what mind they have.
tgt_text.3055: An ox, stamping on my tongue with sturdy foot,3 restrains me from chattering, though I am versed in it, 0 Cyrnus.
tgt_text.3056: But still it is impossible to escape from what is fated to suffer ;
tgt_text.3057: and what I am fated to suffer I nowise fear to endure.
tgt_text.3058: Into a vast unspeakable evil4 are we come, wherein above all, O Cyrnus, the fate of death may seize us both together.
tgt_text.3059: But they who dishonour their parents, when growing old, for these, Cyrnus, there is no place of esteem..
tgt_text.3060: Neither aid any tyrant in the hopes that 'tis matter of gain.
tgt_text.3061: 2 nor slay him, when you have entered into covenants sworn before the gods.
tgt_text.3062: How bath our spirit had the heart to sing to the flute- player ?3 but from the forum is seen the limit of the land, which maintains with her fruits men wearing at feasts and on auburn locks purple garlands.
tgt_text.3063: Nay, come now, Scythian, shave thy hair, and cease from revelling, and lament the fragrant country lost.
tgt_text.3064: By faith have I lost wealth, and by unbelief preserved it:
tgt_text.3065: 4 but the counsel of both is difficult.
tgt_text.3066: All this my property is with the crows and in ruin ;
tgt_text.3067: nor is any of the immortal bless­ ed gods to blame in my judgment:
tgt_text.3068: but man's violence, and much gain, and wrong have thrust me out of many good things into poverty.
tgt_text.3069: There are two fates truly of drinking to wretched mortals, 1 limb-relaxing thirst, and baneful drunkenness.
tgt_text.3070: Now between these I shall abide, nor will you persuade me either not to drink at all, or to be excessively drunken.
tgt_text.3071: Wine, indeed, in other respects is agreeable to me, but in one 'tis disagreeable, to tit, when, having made me drunk, it leads me against a foe.
tgt_text.3072: But when one, being properly above,2 shall have been lowered, then 'tis meet he should go home, having ceased from drinking.
tgt_text.3073: To upset a man well established is easy ;
tgt_text.3074: but to set right that which is ill settled, is difficult.
tgt_text.3075: Spurn the empty-spirited rabble,3 strike them with sharp goad, and place around them a galling yoke.
tgt_text.3076: For no more will you find a populace so fond of despots, among all men, as many as the sun looks down upon.
tgt_text.3078: Jove destroy the man who chooses to de­ ceive his comrade, prating smoothly4 to him.
tgt_text.3079: I knew indeed even before, but much better now, that the mean have no gra­ titude.
tgt_text.3080: Oft hath this city through the baseness of its rulers, like a ship wandering out of its course, driven past the land.
tgt_text.3081: But if any of my friends sees me in any trouble, turning his head away, he does not even choose to look on me:

tgt_text.3361: The Proem is a rhapsody in honour of the Muses.
tgt_text.3362: It opens with a descrip­ tion of their solemn dances on Helicon, and of the hymns which they sing during their nightly visitation of Earth.
tgt_text.3363: The poet then relates their ap­ pearance to himself, and his consequent inspiration;
tgt_text.3364: describes their em­ ployments in Heaven, their birth and dignity;
tgt_text.3365: their influence on kings, minstrels, and bards;
tgt_text.3366: and finishes with invoking their assistance, and proposing his subject.
tgt_text.3367: The COSMOGONY, or Origin of Nature, then com­ mences, and blends into the THEOGONY, or Generation of the Gods, which is continued through the whole poem, and concludes with the race of demigods, or those born from the loves of goddesses and mortals.
tgt_text.3368: The following legendary fables are interwoven episodically with the main sub­ ject:
tgt_text.3369: I. The Conspiracy of Earth and Cronus, or Saturn, against Uranus or Heaven.
tgt_text.3371: The Concealment of the Infant Jupiter.
tgt_text.3373: The Im­ piety and Punishment of Prometheus.
tgt_text.3375: The Creation of Pandora, or Woman.
tgt_text.3376: V. The War of the Gods and Titans.
tgt_text.3378: The Combat of Jupiter and Typhœus.

tgt_text.4893: The Exordium is a rhapsody in praise of Jupiter.
tgt_text.4895: the general economy of Industry and Morals.
tgt_text.4896: In the first division of the subject the state of the world past and present is described, for the pur­ pose of exemplifying the condition of human nature;
tgt_text.4897: which entails on man the necessity of exertion to procure the goods of life ;
tgt_text.4898: and leaves him no alternative but honest industry or unjust violence;
tgt_text.4899: of which the good and evil consequences are respectively illustrated.
tgt_text.4900: Two STRIFES are said to have been sent into the world, the one promoting Dissension, the other Emulation.
tgt_text.4901: Perses is exhorted to abjure the former and embrace the latter:
tgt_text.4902: and an apposite allusion is made to the circumstance of his litigiously disputing the patrimonial estate, of which through the corrup­ tion of the judges he obtained the larger proportion.
tgt_text.4903: The judges are re­ buked, and cheap contentment is apostrophized as the true secret of hap­ piness.
tgt_text.4904: Such is stated to have been the original sense of mankind before the necessity of labour existed.
tgt_text.4905: The origin of labour is deduced from the resentment of Jupiter against Prometheus;
tgt_text.4906: which resentment led to the creation of PANDORA, or WomAN ;
tgt_text.4907: who is described with her attributes, and is represented as bringing into the world a casket of evils.
tgt_text.4908: The de­ generacy of man is then traced through successive ages.
tgt_text.4909: The three first ages are respectively distinguished as golden, silver, and brazen.
tgt_text.4910: The fourth has no metallic distinction, but is described as the heroic age, and as embracing the æra of the Trojan war.
tgt_text.4911: The fifth is styled the iron age, and, according to the poet, is that in which he lives.
tgt_text.4912: The general corrup­ tion of mankind in this age is detailed, and Modesty and Justice are represented as taking their flight to heaven.
tgt_text.4913: A pointed allusion to the corrupt administration of the laws in his own particular instance is intro­ duced in a fable typical of oppression.
tgt_text.4914: Justice is described as invisibly following those who violate her decrees with avenging power, and as lamenting in their streets the wickedness of a corrupted people.
tgt_text.4915: The temporal blessings of an upright nation are contrasted with -the temporal evils which a wicked nation draws down from an angry Providence.
tgt_text.4916: Holy Daemons are represented as walking the earth, and keeping watch over the actions of men.
tgt_text.4917: Justice is again introduced as carrying her com­ plaints to the feet of Jupiter, and as obtaining that the crimes of rulers be visited on their people.
tgt_text.4918: A pathetic appeal is then made to these rulers, in their judicial capacity, to forsake injustice.
tgt_text.4919: After some further exhorta­ tions to virtue and industry, and a number of unconnected precepts, the poet enters on the GEORGICAL part of his subject;
tgt_text.4920: which contains the prognostics of the seasons of agricultural labour, and rules appertaining to wood-felling, carpentry, ploughing, sowing, reaping, thrashing, vine- dressing, and the vintage.
tgt_text.4921: This division of the subject includes a descrip­ tion of Winter and of a repast in Summer.
tgt_text.4922: The poet then treats of navigation;
tgt_text.4923: and concludes with some desultory precepts of religion, morality, and superstition:
tgt_text.4924: and lastly, with a specification of DAYS ;
tgt_text.4925: which are divided into holy, auspicious and inauspicious, mixed, and in­ termediary, or such as are entitled to no remarkable observance.

tgt_text.7854: Cypselus was entirely out of date;
tgt_text.7855: and his son Periander, who succeeded him as tyrant of Corinth, had died after a long reign, in the last year of the 48th Olympiad (see Fasti Hellenici).
tgt_text.7856: But Cypselus was the first un- derminer and destroyer of the Dorian aristocracy;
tgt_text.7857: having sup­ planted the oligarchy of the Bacchiadæ, he had continued banish­ ing and destroying without intermission during the whole of his life;
tgt_text.7858: and his son (after the usual interval of milder government in a new reign) had resumed his father's policy, and pushed it to a more severe extreme.
tgt_text.7859: Cypselus was a tyrant and a usurper, but the system of which he was the personification was persevered in after his death.
tgt_text.7860: The principle upon which his usurpation had been founded (a hatred of the hereditary oligarchies) still continued to influence the policy of Corinth, and manifested itself in their support of the democratic revolution of Athens and Megara.
tgt_text.7861: This was the point which Theognis (doubly a sufferer from the effects of this policy) meant to mark;
tgt_text.7862: and if this view of the subject is admissible, his intention in characterizing the Corinthians as a Cypselizing race may be capable of explanation.

tgt_text.0: Uabel(lat. iadula, von tari, reden) bedeutet ursprüng­ lich Rede, Erzählung überhaupt, besonders aber eine erdich­ tete Erzählung, weßhalb auch der erdichtete Stoff eines Epos, Drama u. dgl. die Fabel des Gedichtes heißt.
tgt_text.1: Allein hievon ist hier die Rede nicht.
tgt_text.2: Wir haben es lediglich mit der sogenannten äsopischen Fabel ') zu thun, mit welchem Namen man eine erdichtete Erzählung bezeichnet, in der allge­ meine moralische Wahrheiten und Klugheitslehren unter dem Bilde irgend eines, der lebenden oder leblosen Welt entnomme­ nen, Vorfalles veranschaulicht und eingeprägt werden.
tgt_text.3: Diese Dichtungsart war anfangs reine Naturpoesie, hervorgegangen aus dem angeborenen Wohlgefallen des Menschen an den Dingen um ihn her.
tgt_text.4: Ihr Ursprung datirt schon in das früheste Alter­ thum zurück, wo der Mensch noch in unmittelbarer Umgebung mit den Thieren lebte, in ihrem Treiben und ihrer verschie­ denen Art sich zu äußem gar manche Seite kennen lernte, von der aus sie ihm Vorbilder für menschliches Denken und Han­ deln sein konnten, ihre Sprache vernahm und selbst mit ihnen sprach.
tgt_text.5: Von da aus war es nur noch ein Schritt weiter, ihnen geradezu menschliche Worte in den Mund zu legen, und Tradition und Dichtkunst trugen dann vollends das Ihrige dazu bei, sich ganze Geschichten von ihnen zu erzählen.
tgt_text.6: Zuerst sind es die größeren einheimischen vierfüßigen Thiere, die in der Fabel jedes Volkes ihre Rolle spielen;
tgt_text.7: die Vögel stehen dem Menschen schon entfernter:
tgt_text.8: nur mit wenigen, wie etwa dem Hahn, Storch, Sperling, Raben, Kranich, Adler, der Krähe, Lerche :
tgt_text.9: c. ist er näher vertraut, und noch seltener kom­ men Pflanzen und Mineralien vor, da die Aeußerung ihres Lebens eine viel unmerklichere ist, als die der Thierwelt.
tgt_text.10: In dem Verhältniß aber, als die Fabel immer künstlicher ausge­ bildet wurde, traten auch immer mehr Geschöpfe in ihr auf;
tgt_text.11: der ganze Olymp mit seinen mythischen Gestalten, sogar per­ sonificirte Begriffe wurden darein eingeführt.
tgt_text.12: So wurde die Thierfabel aus der Naturdichtung allmälig zur allegorisch­ didaktischen, aber auch in letzterer Gestalt ist sie außerordent­ lich alt.Schon in den frühesten Zeiten war überhaupt bei den Orientalen die Einkleidung in eine Fabel eine sehr beliebte Art der Belehrung und Zurechtweisung.
tgt_text.13: In Indien, dem Ursitze der geistigen Cultur, welche sich zugleich mit der Bevöl­ kerung von hier über die östliche Halbkugel unserer Erde aus­ gebreitet hat, erzählte man sich Fabeln schon viele Jahrhun­ derte vor Aesop.
tgt_text.14: Ebenso finden sich in den heiligen Schriften der Hebräer mehrfache Spuren dieser Dichtart, wie z. B. Richter 9, 8—15 Jotham's Fabel von den Bäumen, die sich einen König wählten, II.

tgt_text.18: iAber auch bei den Griechen selbst finden sich schon lange vor Aesop Fabeln vor.

tgt_text.20: ArchilochoS aus Paros (um 600 v. Chr.) griff in zwei Fabeln „vom Adler und Fuchse" und „vom Fuchse und Affen" den Lykam­ bes an, der ihm seine ihm früher versprochene Tochter vorent­ hielt, um sie mit einem Reichern zu vermählen.

Chr.) warnte seine Landsleute, als sie den Phalaris zu ihrem Feldherrn machen wollten, durch die von Aristoteles ') aufbewahrte Fabel von dem Pferde, das sich, um Rache an dem Hirsch zu nehmen, vom Men­ schen einen Zaum anlegen ließ und nun diesem dienstbar wurde.Aus dem Bisherigen ergibt sich denn zur Genüge, daß.

tgt_text.34: Als hier ein Gärtner gegen Erstern seine Ver­ wunderung darüber äußerte, daß die Kräuter, welche von sich selbst wachsen, so groß werden und leicht zunehmen, während solche, die man mit großer Mühe und vielem Eifer säet, setzt oder Pflanzt, weit weniger groß werden und zunehmen, da nahm Aesop, weil sein Herr keinen Aufschluß hierüber zu geben wußte, das Wort und sagte:
tgt_text.35: „ist es nicht wahr, daß eine rechte Mutter ihrem Kinde mehr Gutes thut, als eine Stiefmutter?"
tgt_text.36: Und als der Gärtner dieß bestätigte, fuhr er fort:

tgt_text.38: Die Erde ist eine Mutter aller Gewächse;
tgt_text.39: die Kräuter, welche sie von sich selbst zeuget, sind ihre rechten Kinder, die aber, so man mit Kunst in sie hineinpflanzt, ihre Stiefkinder;
tgt_text.40: doch kann der Mensch durch Fleiß und Sorgfalt der Erde noch viel abgewinnen.
tgt_text.42: Von Xanthos wurde Aesop an den ebenfalls auf Samos wohnhaften Philosophen Jadmon verkauft, der ihm wegen seiner Tugendhaftigkeit und seines musterhaften Verhaltens später die Freiheit schenkte.
tgt_text.43: Dieses ihm zu Theil gewordene Glück benützte er dann zu Reisen in verschiedene Länder und erwarb sich durch seine Kenntnisse und Lebensweisheit bald einen so ausgebreiteten Ruf, daß ihn sogar Krö sos an seinen Hof kommen ließ, wo er den als Gesetzgeber Athens so be­ rühmt gewordenen Solon kennen gelernt und sich dessen Freundschaft erworben haben soll.Eben so wenig, als das Geburtsjahr Aesops, kennen wir das Jahr, in welchem er starb, mit Bestimmtheit;
tgt_text.44: Eusebius und Suidas geben als solches 560 v. Chr. an.
tgt_text.45: Ueber die Art seines Todes erzählt Plutarch (1. o.):
tgt_text.46: Von Krösos nach Delphi gesendet, um dem Apollo ein feierliches Opfer zu bringen und zugleich unter die Bewohner jener Stadt in des Königs Namen eine bedeutende Summe Geldes zu vertheilen, zog sich Aesop den Haß derselben dadurch zu, daß er ihnen ihren Müßiggang vorwarf, indem sie lediglich von dem Ver­ dienste lebten, der ihnen durch den Aufenthalt der das Orakel des Apollo besuchenden Fremden zufloß, und nach vollbrachtem Opfer das für die Delphier bestimmte Geld, weil sie dessen unwürdig wären, wieder an Krösos zurückschickte.
tgt_text.47: Um ihn daher aus irgend einem rechtsgiltigen Grunde verderben zu kön­ nen, verbargen sie eine goldene Opferschale unter seine Geräth­ schasten, beschuldigten ihn, dieselbe aus dem Tempel entwen­ det zu haben, sprachen das Todesurtheil über ihn aus und vollzogen solches dadurch, daß sie ihn von einem AbHange des Felsens Hhampe, auf welchem ihre Stadt lag, herabstürzten ').
tgt_text.48: Nach Aesops Tode soll Apollo ^), um das an ihm verübte Unrecht zu bestrafen, den Delphiern Seuchen und Hungers­ noth gesandt haben, worauf sie sich feierlich zu jeder Genug­ thuung für ihr Verbrechen bereit erklärten.
tgt_text.49: Jadmon von Samos, ein Enkel des letzten Herrn Aesops (s. o.) versöhnte sie endlich dadurch mit dem erzürnten Gotte, daß er ihnen den Rath ertheilte, dem unschuldig Gemordeten eine Bildsäule zu errichten, was auch geschah, worauf sie dann von den über sie verhängten Strafen wieder befreit wurden.
tgt_text.50: Aesop hat keine einzige seiner Fabeln aufgeschrieben, son­ dern er trug sie blos mündlich in der ungekünstelten Ausdrucks­ weise des Volkes vor, um desto nachdrücklicher auf dieses wir­ ken zu können.
tgt_text.51: So mögen sie sich denn auf dem Wege der Tradition durch die zwei bis drei nächsten Generationen ziem­ lich unverfälscht, natürlich aber blos dem wesentlichen Inhalte, nicht dem Wortlaute nach erhalten haben.
tgt_text.52: Im weitern Ver­ laufe der Zeit wurden dann selbstverständlich die Abweichun­ gen von der ursprünglichen Erzählung immer bedeutender und willkürlicher.
tgt_text.53: Auf keinen Fall aber lassen sich die den einzel­ nen Fabeln beigefügten moralischen Nutzanwendungen auf Aesop selbst zurückführen.
tgt_text.54: An diesen oft gar wässerigen und mitunter ganz unpassenden Anhängseln — mögen sie herkom­ men wo immer sie wollen — trägt Aesop, der mündliche Er­ zähler, sicherlich keine Schuld.
tgt_text.55: Lag doch die Moral schon in der Veranlassung des Gedichtes selbst;
tgt_text.56: dadurch, daß er die Zuhörer dessen Zweck selber errathen ließ, mußte es ihnen ungleich anziehender erscheinen, als wenn denselben die trockene Belehrung, gleich dem hinkenden Boten, auf dem Fuße nach­ folgte.
tgt_text.57: Auch aus dem Umstände, daß bei vershciedenen grie­ chischen Schriftstellern des Alterthums, wie z. B. bei Euripides, Aristophanes, Aristoteles, Plutarch u. a. äsopischer Fabeln Erwähnung geschieht, oder auf solche, oder auf einzelne in ihnen enthaltene Gedanken angespielt wird, sowie daraus, daß Sokrates im Kerker mehrere derselben in Verse brachte '), darf nicht gefolgert werden, daß es je von Aesop schriftlich abge­ faßte Fabeln gegeben habe.
tgt_text.58: Das aber ist ausgemacht, daß verhältnißmäßig schon frühe Sammlungen sogenannter äso­ pischer Fabeln verfertigt wurden, wie denn Diogenes von Laerte ') den um 300 v. Chr. lebenden, in der Geschichte Athens und nachher am ägyptischen Hofe so berühmt geworde­ nen Demetrius aus Phalerum ausdrücklich als einen sol­ chen Sammler namhaft macht.
tgt_text.59: Indessen begnügte man sich nicht damit, solche Fabeln, die als äsopisch galten und die man bereits vorfand, zu sammeln, sondern man verfertigte auch ganz neue und legte ihnen dessen ungeachtet gleichen Ursprung mit jenen bei.
tgt_text.60: Das geschah be­ sonders in den Rednershculen, welche, seitdem die Römer sich Griechenland und nachher Asien unterworfen hatten, fast in allen bedeutenden Städten ihres Reiches bestanden.
tgt_text.61: Die Leh­ rer der Redekunst verfaßten theils selbst für ihre Schüler Fa­ beln, theils gaben sie diesen einen von ihnen erfundenen oder aus den dem Aesop beigelegten Fabeln entnommenen Stoff zu eigener Bearbeitung auf und betitelten beiderlei Erzeugnisse äsopische Fabeln, mochten diese auch den älteren noch so unähnlich sein.
tgt_text.62: Dergleichen geschah unter anderen in Plu­ tarch's Rednerschule zu Rom, in der des Aphthonios^) zu Antiochien, von welch letzterem Lehrer der Redekunst wir jetzt noch eine prosaische Bearbeitung von vierzig äsopischen Fabeln besitzen.
tgt_text.63: Im ersten Jahrhundert v. Ch>, unter Augustus, bear­ beitete Babrius die äsopischen Fabeln in Choliamben Syntipas übersetzte sie in's Syrische und Michael Andreo­ pulos aus dem Syrischen wieder zurück in's Griechische').
tgt_text.64: Jgnatius Magister oder Diaconus, L78 als Patriarch von Constantinopel gestorben, faßte 53 Fabeln des Babrius in Tetrasticha.
tgt_text.65: Eine prosaische Sammlung äsopischer Fabeln legte der schon oben erwähnte Maximus Planudes um das I. 1327 an, die in zwei Recensionen auf uns gekommen ist.
tgt_text.66: In der ersten Recension ') machte sie zuerst Bonus Accur­ sius (Buonaccorso) aus einer ihm gehörigen Handschrift zu Mailand ohne Jahreszahl (1479. 4.) durch den Druck bekannt.
tgt_text.67: Sie enthält 144 Fabeln nebst der lateinischen Uebersetzung des Rimicius von Arezzo und die schon oben angeführte, dem Planudes zugeschriebene Biographie Aesops.
tgt_text.68: In neuerer Zeit ließ I. M. Heusinger diese Sammlung, vermehrt mit fünf Fabeln und mit Hudsons Anmerkungen zuerst Eisenach und Leipzig 1741.
tgt_text.70: Verbessert erschien seine Ausgabe durch Ch. A. Klotz ebendas.
tgt_text.71: 1776 und zuletzt durch G. H. Schäfer Leipz.
tgt_text.72: 1818, welcher in einem Anhange 28 von Rochefort aus Pariser Handschriften und fünf von I. G. Husch ke aus einem vortrefflichen Augsburger Codex bekannt gemachte Fabeln hinzugefügt hat.
tgt_text.73: Diese im Ganzen aus 182 Fabeln bestehende Sammlung haben wir, als die bei Weitem verbreitetste, dem Inhalte nach unserer Uebersetzung zu Grunde gelegt und nur noch Nro.
tgt_text.74: 158 der neuesten Samm­ lung von C. Halm (I^ips. 1863. 8.) „Herakles, die Tugend und das Laster" (aus Xenoph.
tgt_text.76: II, §. 21, 599.) beigefügt, hinsichtlich des Textes haben wir uns an die Halm'­ sche Recension gehalten.
tgt_text.77: Ein Adler und ein Fuchs waren Freunde geworden und beschlos­ sen ihre Wohnung nahe bei einander zu nehmen, weil sie das Zusam­ menwohnen für ein Befestigungsmittel der Freundschaft hielten.
tgt_text.78: Jener erbaute sein Nest auf einem hohen Baume, dieser warf in dem ganz nahe gelegenen Buschwerk Junge.
tgt_text.79: Wie nun der Fuchs eines Tages nach Futter ausgegangen war, flog der Adler, dem es eben an Speise fehlte, auf das Gebüsch herab, raubte dessen Junge und verzehrte sie gemeinschaftlich mit seiner Brut.
tgt_text.80: Der Fuchs, der bei seiner Zurück- kunst das Geschehene inne ward, betrübte sich ^fast^ nicht so sehr über den Tod seiner Kinder, wie über die ihm mangelnde Gelegenheit zur Rache:
tgt_text.81: denn als Landthier war er nicht im Stande den mit Flügeln Begabten zu verfolgen.
tgt_text.82: Er blieb deßhalb in der Ferne stehen und rief — das Einzige, was der Schwache thun kann — seinem Feinde Verwünschungen nach.
tgt_text.83: Nicht lange nachher opferten sLeute^ auf dem Felde eine Ziege;
tgt_text.84: da flog der Adler ^ebenfalls wieder^ herab, raubte ein Theil des Opfers sammt den glühenden Kohlen und trug es in sein Nest.
tgt_text.85: Wie hernach in Folge eines heftigen Windes die Flamme hoch aufloderte, fielen die Adlerjungen, welche noch nicht flügge waren, >wieZ gebraten auf die Erde herab;
tgt_text.86: der Fuchs aber lief hinzu und verzehrte sie alle vor den Augen des Adlers.Die Fabel lehrt, daß die Verletzer eines Freundschaftsbündnisses, wenn sie auch der Rache der Beleidigten wegen Mangels an Stärke Ivon Seiten dieser^ entfliehen, dennoch der göttlichen Strafe nicht ent­ gehen.Ein von einem Adler verfolgter Hase flüchtete sich in das Lager eines Kothkäfers und flehte ihn um Schutz an.
tgt_text.87: Dieser richtete an den Adler die Bitte, seinen Schützling nicht umzubringen, und beschwor ihn Zugleich) bei dem höchsten Zeus T), seine Kleinheit doch ja nicht zu Verachten.
tgt_text.88: Allein der Adler schlug ergrimmt mit seiner Schwinge auf den Kothkäfer, nahm den Hasen mit sich fort und verzehrte ihn.
tgt_text.89: Der Kothkäfer flog dem Adler nach, um dessen Nest ausfindig zu machen, und dort angekommen wälzte er ihm die Eier heraus und vernichtete sie.
tgt_text.90: Dieser, auf's Höchste aufgebracht, wie Jemand sich Solches unter- stehen könne, baute zum zweiten Male ein Nest an einem höher gelege­ nen Orte;
tgt_text.91: aber auch hier machte es ihm der Kothkäfer wieder ebenso.
tgt_text.92: Ganz und gar rathlos, stieg nun der Adler hinauf zu Zeus (dessen geheiligter Vogel er heißt), legte diesem seine dritte Brut in den Schooß, vertraute sie dem Gotte und bat ihn inständig, ihr seinen Schutz zu gewähren Jetzt machte der Kothkäfer eine Kugel aus Mist, flog damit in die Höhe und legte sie dem Zeus in den Schooß.
tgt_text.93: Zeus stand auf, um den Morast von sich abzuschütteln, warf aber hiebei die Eier un­ versehens auseinander, die im Herabfallen ^denn auch) zerbrachen.
tgt_text.94: Wie er von dem Käfer erfuhr, daß er dieß aus Rache gegen den Adler gethan habe, (denn dieser hatte nicht blos den Käfer gekränkt, sondern sich auch an Zeus selbst versündigt), sagte er zu dem Adler bei dessen Zurückkunft:
tgt_text.95: der Kothkäfer sei es, der ihm sothane Kränkung zufüge, und zwar thue er ihm dieses verdientermaßen.
tgt_text.96: Weil er jedoch das Geschlecht der Adler nicht aussterben lassen wollte, gab er dem Koth­ käfer den Rath, sich mit dem Adler auszusöhnen.
tgt_text.97: Hiezu war jener nicht zu bewegen, weßhalb ^der Gott) die Brut der Adler in eine an­ dere Zeit verlegte, in welcher die Kothkäfer noch nicht zum Vorschein kommen.
tgt_text.99: Niemanden gering zu achten und wohl zu be­ denken, daß es Keinen gibt, der, wenn man ihn mißhandelt, nicht im Stande wäre, sich dafür zu rächen.
tgt_text.100: Eine Nachtigall saß auf einem Baume und sang nach Gewohn­ heit ßhr Lied).
tgt_text.101: Da flog ein hungeriger Habicht, der sie erblickte, hinzu und ergriff sie.
tgt_text.102: Im Angefichte des Todes bat die Nachtigall den Ha­ bicht, sie doch nicht zu fressen, denn sie reiche ja nicht hin, seinen Magen zu sättigen;
tgt_text.103: wenn er Nahrung bedürfe, möge er sich unter den Vögeln nach etwas Größerem umsehen.
tgt_text.104: Da nahm der Habicht das Wort und entgegnete:
tgt_text.105: „ich müßte wohl ein ^rechter) Thor sein, wenn ich die schon in meinen Händen befindliche Beute losließe und etwas Anderem, das sich mir noch nicht zeigt, nachginge."Die Fabel lehrt, daß es auch unter den Menschen solche Unver­ ständige gibt, die in der Hoffnung auf mehreres Ungewisse das, was sie schon in Händen haben, wieder fahren lassen.Ein Fuchs und ein Bock stiegen, vom Durste getrieben, in einen Brunnen hinab.
tgt_text.106: Nachdem sie getrunken hatten, schaute sich der Bock um, wie wieder heraufzukommen wäre;
tgt_text.108: „sei guten Muthes, ich habe etwas Ersprießliches ersonnen, das zu unserer Bei­ der Rettung dient.
tgt_text.109: Wenn du dich aufrecht hinstellst, die vorderen Füße an die Wand stemmst und zugleich die Hörner vorwärts neigst, will ich mit Hilfe deines Rückens und deiner Hörner hinaufspringen und, außerhalb des Brunnens angelangt, sodann auch dich von da hinauf­ ziehen."
tgt_text.110: Auf das hin leistete der Bock bereitwillig Dienst;
tgt_text.111: der Andere sprang so aus dem Brunnen heraus und hüpfte voll Vergnügen um dessen Rand herum.
tgt_text.112: Der Bock aber machte ihm Vorwürfe, daß er die Uebertzinkunft nicht erfüllt habe.
tgt_text.114: „besäßest du so viel Verstand, wie Haare an deinem Bart, so wärest du nicht ^in die Tiefe) hinabgestiegen, ohne dich vorher nach dem Rückwege umzu­ schauen.
tgt_text.116: Die Fabel lehrt, daß gleicherweise auch der kluge Mann zuvor den Ausgang seiner Handlungen erwägen und erst dann an ihre Aus­ führung gehen solle..Ein Fuchs, der noch nie einen Löwen gesehen hatte, gerieth, als er durch irgend einen Zufall einem solchen begegnete, so sehr in Furcht, daß es ihn um ein Kleines das Leben gekostet hätte.
tgt_text.117: Als er ihn spä­ ter zum zweiten Male sah, fürchtete er sich zwar simmer nochZ, doch nicht mehr so, wie das erste Mal.
tgt_text.118: Beim dritten Anblicke wuchs sein Muth so, daß er sich ihm näherte und eine Unterredung mit ihm an­ knüpfte.Die Fabel lehrt, daß die Gewohnheit auch zu furchtbaren Dingen den Zugang leicht macht.
tgt_text.119: Eine Katze, die einen Hahn erwischt hatte, suchte nach einem trif­ tigen Vorwande, um denselben zu fressen.
tgt_text.120: Dem zufolge beschuldigte sie ihn, daß er durch sein nächtliches Geschrei den Menschen lästig werde und sie des Schlafes nicht genießen lasse.
tgt_text.122: er thue Ha^> dieses zu deren Nutzen, damit sie zu ihren Berufs­ geschäften aufgeweckt würden, rückte die Katze mit der neuen Beschul­ digung heraus, daß er freventlich wider die Natur handle, weil er seiner seigenen^ Mutter und seinen Schwestern beiwohne.
tgt_text.123: Der Hahn hielt ihr zwar entgegen:
tgt_text.124: auch dieß thue er zum Nutzen seiner Besitzer, indem ihnen dadurch viele Eier gelegt würden;
tgt_text.126: „wenn du auch noch so reich an scheinbaren Entschuldigungsgrün­ den bist, so will doch ich nicht ohne Speise bleiben", und verzehrte ihn.Die Fabel lehrt, daß die böse Natur, die snun einmalj sündigen will, wenn sie es unter keinem zulässigen Vorwande kann, unverhohs len Sünde begeht.
tgt_text.127: Einem in der Falle gefangenen Fuchs, der, nachdem ihm der Schwanz abgehauen worden, wieder entkommen war, wurde wegen dieses Schimpfes sein Leben ganz unerträglich.
tgt_text.128: Er beschloß daher, das Gleiche auch den anderen Füchsen vorzushclagen, um unter dem allgemeinen Körpermangel die eigene Schande zu verbergen.
tgt_text.129: Dem zufolge ließ er sie sämmtlich zusammenkommen und redete ihnen zu, die Schwänze abzuhauen, weil ja dieses Glied nicht blos häßlich sei, son­ dern sogar als unnütze Last an MnemZ hänge.
tgt_text.130: Da nahm aber Einer aus ihrer Mitte das Wort und sagte:
tgt_text.131: „o du, der du bist! brächte das dir selbst keinen Vortheil, so würdest du es auch uns nichtanrathen.
tgt_text.132: "Die Fabel lehrt, daß schlechte Leute nicht aus wohlwollender Ge­ sinnung ihren Nebenmenshcen Rath ertheilen, sondern nur, wenn dieß ihnen selber Nutzen bringt.Ein Fuchs, der auf einen Zaun gestiegen war, glitt aus und war eben im Begriff herabzufallen, als er snoch) einen Dornbusch er­ faßte um sich daran zu halten.
tgt_text.133: Als er hiebei an dessen Stacheln seine Füße verwundete und Schmerzen empfand, sagte er zu demselben:
tgt_text.135: ich hatte meine Zuflucht zu dir als meinem Helfer genom­ men, und du hast mich noch schlimmer zugerichtet."
tgt_text.136: „Im Gegentheil" — erwiderte der Dornbusch — „du hast gefehlt, daß du dich an mir halten wolltest, der ich Alles festzuhalten gewohnt bin.
tgt_text.137: "Die Fabel lehrt, daß es gleichfalls unter den Menschen ssolche) Thoren gibt, die ihre Zuflucht zu Helfern nehmen, in deren Natur es mehr liegt zu schaden.
tgt_text.138: Ein FuchS und ein Krokodil stritten sich über ihre edle Abkunft.
tgt_text.139: Das Krokodil zählte viel Rühmliches von dem Glänze seiner Vorfah­ ren her, daß dieselben Vorsteher der Ringschulen (Gymnasiarchen)') ge­ wesen seien.
tgt_text.140: Da fiel ihm der Fuchs in die Rede:
